editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Lately preſented in the priuate houſe at Blacke Friers
LONDON, ¶Printed by Thomas Harper for Iohn Waterſon, and are to be ſold at the ſigne of the Crowne, in Paules Churchyard. 1630.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT Honourable, The Earle of DORSET, &c.
div.p:
THE vnciuill ignorance of the People, had depriu'd this humble worke of life; but that your Lordſhips approbation, ſtept in, to ſuccour it. Thoſe many that came with reſolution to diſpraiſe (knowing your Lordſhips iudgement, to be powerfull, aboue their malice) were eyther corrected to an vnderſtanding, or modeſty: And this large benefit, hath betray'd your Lordſhip to a Dedication. I am bold to beleeue, fancies of this compoſure, haue beene nobly entertayn'd, by the most knowing Princes of the World: The ignorance,
that begets the change in this our age, it may become your Lordſhips example, to correct, mee to lament; if ſo tame a paſsion, can poſſeſſe a Poet, and one, exalted with a hope to be receiu'd

closer.signed: Your Lordſhips humble Seruant, WILLIAM D'AVENANT.

div.head: To my Friend M. D'AVENANT, on his legitimate Poeme.
div.l: EVen ſo the ſilly Midas iudg'd of old
Twixt Pan and great Apollo. As this bold
Herd, of his race, that th'untun'd Pipe admire,
And heare thy ſtraynes, as the dull Aſſe the Lyre.
What wonder then, if thou the lawfull Son
Of Phaebus, taſte what was to him begun.
Hence, giddy fooles; run to the noyſe they make
At Paris-garden; or your ſelues betake
To the new Motion, the fine Puppet playes,
And there adore. Commend the learned layes
That make a din about the ſtreets, or els
Extoll the Iewes-trumpe, or the morris bells.
Theſe, your great heads may manage. Only let
The wiſer few, (whoſe bleſſed eares haue met
The harmony that all the Muſes make,
And from thoſe heauenly ſounds aſſurance take,
That thou ſing'ſt the ſame tunes) admitted be
To thy Seraphyck muſicke, and ſet free
To entertayne their ſoules in that high quire,
Which, not weake fooles, but ſuch as know, admire.

div.head: To my worthy Friend, M. D'AVENANT, Vpon his Excellent Play, The Iuſt Italian.
div.l: ILe not misſpend in prayſe, the narrow roome
I borrow in this leafe; the Garlands bloome
From thine owne ſeedes, that crowne each glorious page
Of thy triumphant worke; the ſullen Age
Requires a Satyre. What ſtarre guides the ſoule
Of theſe our froward times, that dare controule,
Yet dare not learne to iudge? When didſt thou flie
From hence, cleare, candid Ingenuity?
I haue beheld, when pearchd on the ſmooth brow
Of a fayre modeſt troope, thou didſt allow
Applauſe to ſlighter workes; but then the weake
Spectator, gaue the knowing leaue to ſpeake.
Now noyſe preuayles, and he is taxd for drowth
Of wit, that with the crie, ſpends not his mouth.
Yet aske him, reaſon why he did not like;
Him, why he did; their ignorance will ſtrike
Thy ſoule with ſcorne, and Pity: marke the places
Prouoke their ſmiles, frownes, or diſtorted faces,
When, they admire, nod, ſhake the head: they'le be
A ſcene of myrth, a double Comedie.
But thy ſtrong fancies (raptures of the brayne,
Dreſt in Poetique flames) they entertayne
As a bold, impious reach; for they'l ſtill ſlight
All that exceeds Red Bull, and Cockepit flight.
Theſe are the men in crowded heapes that throng
To that adulterate ſtage, where not a tong
Of th'untun'd Kennell, can a line repeat
Of ſerious ſenſe: but like lips, meet like meat;
Whilſt the true brood of Actors, that alone
Keepe naturall vnſtrayn'd Action in her throne
Behold their Benches bare, though they rehearſe
The tearſer Beaumonts or great Iohnſons verſe.
Repine not Thou then, ſince this churliſh fate
Rules not the ſtage alone; perhaps the State
Hath felt this rancour, where men great and good,
Haue by the Rabble beeene miſunderſtood.
So was thy Play; whoſe cleere, yet lofty ſtrayne,
Wiſemen, that gouerne Fate, ſhall entertayne.

list.item: Florello A caſt ſoldier his brother.

div.head: Scene the firſt.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: THis puzles my beliefe: the ſickly Moone
Hath not yet twice expir'd her vſuall 〈◊〉
Since you did mingle Soules, and can 〈◊〉
That ſhe ſo ſoone recoyles from grac •
Harmonious quiet of your bed?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: My Deare
Meruolle ſhe is loſt: As well may I
Collect the ſcatter'd windes into a bagge,
Or from the watry ſurface ſcrape the gilt
Reflections of the Sunne, as bring her heart
Within the quiet liſt of wiues that will
Obay and loue.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Can the Duke (her Vnkle)
Giue an encouragement to her reuolt,
Maintaine the females Charter 'gainſt the male?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Him, and his ſupreame title ſhe ſtill 〈◊〉
To iuſtifie the glory of her birth,
And then recites the Vilages and wealth,
She brought to me for dowre, in parallell
With what I formerly poſſeſſ'd, ſhe doth
Affront my memorie with ſtories of
My leane and niggard fate, and vrging then
Her vaſt ſupplies, doeth challenge leaue to call
Her pride and rigour iuſt.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: This griefe is of
Sad quality!

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The heart hangs heauie on
The ſtrings, when it alone containes the cauſe
And knowledge of its weight: for troubled windes
In their diſperſion looſe their ſtrength; ſo griefes,
Whilſt th'are reueal'd, diminiſh from themſelues.
But the calamities, that doe perplex
The Nuptiall bed, are of a propertie
Recluſe, and muſt be hidden euen from friends:
For on ſuch ſecrets Fame doeth feede with fierce,
And meagre appetite▪ and as ſwift Fame
Doeth trauaile with them, they increaſe. So much
Comerce I haue with humane Arts, that I
Can ſteepe my Gall in my owne teares; and make
That ſalt which ſhe intended bitter; Shew
Her crime to ſpring, not from poyſon'd mallice,
But from the feminine miſtakes of wit:
For moderne Courts now preach, wit doeth reſide
In Ladies ſubtle riots, and their pride.

div.stage: Enter Florello, Roſſa, Molard: in ſouldierly meane habits.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Behold your brother (ſir) whoſe ſafe returne,
This morne I mention'd to your eare—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy growth
Hath ſo orereach'd my ſight, that I'm eſtrang'd
To my beſt blood: and but, thy figure in
My heart I weare (by which my memory's
Enform'd) I ſhould not know I had thee heere—

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I reckon this the chiefe delight I ha • e
Receiu'd on Earth. And (ſir) your loue is of
Such ſou'raigne qualitie, a little ſoone
Will ouercharge my ſenſe. Giue but a part
To me, the reſt conferre vpon my friends—
Who, though in witherd habits, doe deſerue,
Societie with Kings: for neuer yet,
Did bolder Souldiers liſtne to the Drumme.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Gentlemen, ye ſhall enrich my knowledge—

sp.speaker: Roſſa:
sp.l: Noble Signior, vnprofitable loue
Is all our wealth—

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: But wee'le contriue our ſelues
For your beſt vſe.—

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'ue ſayd, conſider them
Within; their weedes are ouergrowne and cheape.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Brother (how ere wiſe fate may anſwere it)
Me thinks, theſe your owne robes are not o'th right
Tyrian dy; nor hath the rich weight of your
Tall Plume the Eſtridge rob'd of both her winges.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Euen thus (ſir) poore, and with ſmall victory
Am I return'd from our caſt Troopes. Our pay
Reſts in Areres, and Piſa's loſt: But you
(I heare) haue fond a Iewell, that containes
All price and luſtre; and you doe weare it
In your boſome: (a noble wife) whoſe birth
And beautie, are alike vnuallu'd as
Her dowre. This I encounterd on
The Lips of Fame; and I made haſte to ſhare
In your ſucceſſe, and put your bounty to
The teſt.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Florello, I haue loſt my ſleepe.
Things differ much from the ſinceritie
Of their firſt growth: Alteza hath forgot
Th'allegiance of a wife, ſhe doth practiſe
How with her riot to impoueriſh States,
And by her loftie pride, to iuſtifie
The immortalitie of fleſh: This Theame
Is ſad; but I will giue you cauſe t'expect
The vtmoſt ſtrength and power of my reliefe.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: You teach my feeble wants a confidence.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: If you a while obſcure your ſelfe (for feare
Your pouertie increaſe her ſcorne) you ſhall
Performe a rationall requeſt. Our young
Faire Siſter, is conceald for the ſame cauſe.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Your mention doth anticipate my loue.
Is our faire Siſter well?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Shee doth enioy
Rare beautie, and much health.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.p: You and your friends, moue backe, and be not ſeene.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Trie Signior Allidore, Antonio's ſonne:
Vtruuio, or the rich Pirracco.
Gritalin, or old Contarini of
Placentia—

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Madam, your husband hath
Proteſted 'gainſt your credit, euen to theſe.

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.p: Slaue, goe force an anſwere more delightfull.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Is't come to this?
I'le be a crooked Spinſter firſt, and with
My ſpittle and my flaxe procure my bread.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: What is the cauſe my Princeſſe thus delight •
In frownes? Anger ſits on her brow like age.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Hence, I ſee thee, and my eyes ſhrinke into
My skull: the Rauen's not ſo ominous and blacke.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Yet vrge the cauſe (my Loue) why your
Defiance is ſo violent and lowd?

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: A Millainois ſhew'd me to day for ſale,
Bright and ſpacious Iewels; but in the darke,
Your puſill malice hath betrai'd my faith,
With Merchants. You haue now my credit wrought
So low, and cheape; I cannot ſtand depoſd
For th'triuiall loane of fortie thouſand crownes.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I would ſuruay a liſt of all your wants,
That I may ſo haue power to haſten the
Redreſſe: Doe you diſlike your properties
Of houſe, your Veſtments, or ſeruice of your
Table; Giue but a name vnto thy wiſh?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: I would haue my Orchard—pau'd with Aggats.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O, and your garden walls raiſd high, t'hedge in
Paraquetos, and th'rhetoricall Dawe?

sp.speaker: Altera.
sp.p: Thou haſt a rude heart, and a bliſterd tongue!

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Well, the firſt day of your coniunction Sir,
I little thought you would haue vſd her thus.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: And I perceiue a maſculine itch beneath
Her left eye; ſhe longs to taſte man.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Come Loue,
Be gentle as thy bridall ſmiles: for by
Thy ſelfe I ſweare, my ſpeech did purpoſe nought▪
To tempt thy ſpleene. Lend me thy melting hand!

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: There— 'tis to reach backe the heart I gaue ye—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: You ſpirits that ſecure the propertie
Of humane loue, be ſtill officiall heere!
Why ſhould we not for euer thus remaine,
Incorporate, and conioyn'd. Tis ſympathie,
And loue, that giues the world continuance
And life. Each ſpecies Loue preſerues. Tis loue
That makes th'eternall Wiſedome thus forbeare
The ſilly crimes of dull humanitie:
And ſuffers vs, like each delighted flie,
To play the triuiall wantons in his eye.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: You preach of loue, but your obedience would
More pleaſure me.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: This argues thy reuolt!
And is a ſtratagem againſt nature.
Thou wouldſt vſurpe the Charter of the male,
Tis my confeſſion, that thy dowre was vaſte
And opulent, and ſuch as may ſupport
Thy titles, and thy birth, with all the pride
And cunning of magnificence. Let my
Sincere phraſe inſtruct thy heart. Reaſſume
The bluſhes of thy youth; with timerous
Modeſtie behaue thy geſture and thy tongue,
And then, thou ſhalt ſtand vp exemplary
To all triumphant Courts: the enuie of
The Eaſterne Queenes: th'Aſtrologers miſtake,
Who ſhall direct their Opticks vnto thee,
As to a new and vnknowne Starre.

sp.speaker: Alteza
sp.l: Siſter!—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The ſmall Muſitions of the aire (whom Queene •
With mimicke falconrie doe pearch vpon
Their fiſts) ſhall be thy food. Thy maides ſhall eate
Young Pelicanes, and Squirils hearts.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy beuiridge ſhall be propheticke, and
Diuine; for thou ſhalt drinke that ſou'raigne dew,
That hangs vpon the frighted Lillies cheeke,
And brew'd with Syrens teares, ſuch as they ſhed
In reall obſequies.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: O bounteous Sir!—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The ſoft entraile o'th Perſian worme, th'Ermines
Palefur, ſhall cloth thy limmes.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thoſe gums and ſpices which the Arabian bird,
Collects to make her tragicke piles, ſhall be
Thy winter fewell▪

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt haue Marmaſets, and Dwarfs, the male
And female too, to procreate in thy houſe;
That thy delights may euer be renew'd.
Thy Iewels ſhall increaſe, as if the lou'd
Indies were thy Quarrie. Th'Almightie Sunne
Shall riſe, and ſee a nobler day breake from
Thy Cabinet, then yet the illuſtrious Eaſt
Ere knew.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: But how will you performe theſe hopes?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The miracle, and power, doe both conſiſt,
In my large wealth.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Death on my Tribe! Your wealth?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: This iteration
Scarce will delight, if it be negatiue.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Canſt thou perſiſt in ſuch accurſed ſchiſme?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Did you not then intend, when you endow'd
Me with your wealth, that I ſhould call it mine?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: By heauen not I. I forfeited the loue
O'th'great Duke (my Vnkle) to marry thee;
That wert a thing ſhrunke from thy fate, and loſt
Vnto the lippes and eyes of men; but yet
In moſt aſſured hope, that thou wouldſt prooue,
An humble and obedient husband.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Th'art more impudent, then the Baſiliske,
Who ſtares i'th bleſſed face of man, vntill
He kill him with his eyes.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Heare Altamont!
For I will giue ſolemnitie vnto
A vow, that ſhall for euermore, diuide
Thee from my bed—

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Deare Madam hold! Each ſence
Of mine doth bluſh, that can perceiue, your wild,
Rebellious wrath. Hath not the Church nam'd him
Your husband, and your Lord?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: M'opinions of
The Church, I'le tell to'th Conclaue, not to you—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Is this the helpe, Diuinitie gaue man?
Snuffe the Moone, ſhe burnes dimme. The Spheares are now
Ill tun'd, and aged nature backward reeles.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Thy anger's vaine. Heere I doe baniſh thee
My bed: And we will neuer more embrace.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I now diuide my houſe:
This ſide is mine, with the dimenſions that
Dependance haue on this ſquare frame: for heere
My familie and I will rule. That ſide
You, and your meagre ragged traine poſſeſſe.
Thou mayſt hencefoorth my neighbour, but no more
My husband be. Charintha, come away—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I muſt purſue, leſt ſhe her anger make
Too lowd, ſo we inuite the publike ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Is not thy brothers wife a pure tame henne?
How doſt thou like her noyſe?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Were ſhe but mine,
I'ld teach her keepe a noyſe too after death.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'ld ſtrippe her skinne o're her eares and
Make a drumme on't.

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.p: She was borne in a ſtorme!

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.p: And begot ſure with the Boeſwayns whiſtle.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Meruolle, you haue nam'd Charintha,
As a precious Virgine, of nature moſt
Remiſſe, a quiet tongue, and ſuch a heart,
As might become an able ſacrifice,
T'expiate the whole world?

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: This I eſteem'd
My iuſtice on her merits, but it ſeemes
Her Siſters documents ore rule her now.
Her dowry is of ample rate, and may
Deſerue the chiefe of our Italian youth.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: What's Dandalo, that ſues to her for loue?

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Dandalo, the Count of Millaine? A thing
Co • poſd of ſpicery and ſtarch! Nature
Contriu'd him in her ſleepe. If's ignorance
Might anſwere for his ſinnes; he would accompt
Amongſt his wealth, the land he has in Heauen.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: I heard you ſay, ſhe neuer ſaw him yet.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Neuer Sir: He wooes her by his letters.
She deſiring a perſonall ſuruay
Ere proſecution of the ſute, he ſent
Her word, he'ld make's addreſſe by ſtealth; but we
Expect him not ere'th'birth of the next Moon.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Will his ariuall be ſo long delay'd?—
Brother! — How thriues your patience ore your wife?

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Some Philoſophicke hope remaines: the ſtorme
Can't laſt, becauſe 'tis ſtill more violent.
Sh'ath tane Caroch for the Pallace, and meanes
Straite to diſgrace me to the Duke
By her complaints.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Florello, I deſire thou'lt not appeare
Before her eye, vntill thy habit's chang'd.
My preſent power ſummes but a thouſand crownes,
Which I haue brought, and proſtrate to thy vſe—

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Sir it is fit your bleſſings were encreaſd;
And that your wife had read your worth.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: My Art betrayes my hopes, or I haue found
A remedy to cure her pride: your helpe
Meruolle, I muſt craue, and with ſwift ſpeed:

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Roſſa, Molard, (friends to my Soule and Braine)
Aduance your ſubtle Eyes! The ſou'raigne mine
Behold, that makes the ſolemne Patriarke dance,
And the anointed King to skippe, as doth
His limber Dwarfe.

sp.speaker: Molard
sp.p: Shall we be tender natur'd, and diuide?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This is the portion will procure vs all
High dignitie and place. Roſſa, you muſt
Find cauſe to number theſe— Goe, ranſome out
Our captiue weedes, and the rich habit I
From Piſa brought: whilſt you (Mollard) with the
Aſſiſtance of theſe few—procure vs fit
Materials to adorne, and put in bright
Aſpect our Corps. Enquire for Pearles: Stones of
The cunningſt ſoyle, we'le like them, and disburſe.

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: Is there ſome aged veſſell now aſleepe
In the Docke, that will pay for her calking?

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.p: Florello, muſt we ſtop the publike leakes?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Ere long we ſhall be great, be able to
Aduance with ſmiles, and with our frownes deſtroy.
You Roſſa, I'le create a Magiſtrate.
Goe practiſe the auſteere Cough. Pale dilinquents
Thou ſhalt learne to ieere, and to ſleepe ore men
Condemn'd.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Thou (my Molard) ſhalt rule in Villages,
Grow popular, and miſtake the Lawes. Thou ſhalt
Delight i'th Kallender: the Rubricke dayes
Thou ſhalt obſerue, and then deſtroy thy beefe.
Whilſt thy dull earthie Tennants feede vntill
They ſmell.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: My Launcepreſado then ſhall ſop
His Cruſt in Cyder and in wine!

sp.speaker: Roſſa▪
sp.l: And my
Dread Corporall ſhall ſinne no more for Leekes,
His Girdle and his ſocks he ſhall vnpawne.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: The ſolitarie Hoſteſſe ſhall no more
Boyle the Carion meate that ſhe muſt truſt,
In her owne teares; Nor with a Requiem bring
The ſeruice vp, as if it were the Haunch
Of her dead Husband.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: The Geographicke Captaine ſhall no more
Studie the Towne Mappe, that's darke walkes may be
Contriu'd through ſlender Allies and through Lanes,
To ſcape his hungrie Creditors abroade.

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: Thy Prouince is Chaldea, thy Father
Was a Rabby!

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Theſe are the victories of wit: by wit
We muſt atchieue our hopes; which to refine
And purifie, with paces doubled let's
Deſcend a Marble vault, there taſte the rich
Legitimate blood of the mighty Grape.
Tis precious as the milke of Queenes; ſuch as
Would teach dull Saturne laugh. It magnifies
The heart, and makes the agill ſpirits dance,
It drownds all thoughts adulterate and ſad;
Inſpires the Prophet, makes the Poet glad.

div.head: Scene the firſt.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I Haue receiu'd a mandate from the Duke,
That will (I feare) increaſe her inſolence.
Like an old Tyrant he beſtowes his threats;
As if his anger did obay his will,
Not iuſtice, nor the Lawes.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Does your wife know
This preparation you haue made to cure
Her haughtineſſe?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: All is diſcouerd to
Her eare: the newes hath taught her boyle her heart
In her owne blood. She now weepes vineger;
Boaſts of reuenge, as if the Thunder were
Her owne.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: T'were fit your pretty Agent heere,
Receiu'd inſtructions how to ſhape her garbe
And port, iuſt as th'imployment doth require.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Her knowledge is already ſatisfi'd.
Alteza's threats ſhall onely mooue her ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I will performe my beſt in your behalfe▪
But I doe feare I am not valiant Sir. Enter Niente.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O, you! that call your ſinnes your duty, that
Obay your Ladies riots out o'zeale!—

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Signior!—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Her honours ſpittle you preſerue
As a Reſtoratiue for your ſalt itch

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: I beſeech ye—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: You thrid in Bracelets too,
The Pearles that drop from her authenticke noſe.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: To cleaue you from the ſcalpe
Vnto the twiſt: to make nine skittles of
Your bo • es, and winde your heratſtrings 'bout my thumbe—

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: O mercy Sir! So rotten are my Limmes
That when you ſtretch your Cheekes and blow on me,
I ſtrait am ſcatter'd into ſand—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Coward!
Creepe ſtrait into my Houreglaſſe then, and there
Eternally diſtinguiſh fatall time— Enter Alteza.

sp.speaker: Alteza..
sp.p: What ſlaue diſturbs the quiet of my Eare?

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Nere looke Sir! I ſerue my Lady; and I
Doe ſcorne to yeeld—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: D'ye briſtle Porcupine?—

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Take heed!— I haue the mallady of France—

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Stay Altamont! withdraw thy violence!
If thou diſorderſt but a haire, that doth
Belong to th'Eyebrow of my meaneſt Groome,
I will proclaime my ſuperioritie
And rule i'th'Streets.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Inſult beneath thy owne low Roofe! This part
O'th'Houſe doth call me ſoueraigne

div.stage: She ſpies Scoperta, and comes neere her.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Is that the Peece you haue ſo magnifi'd,
She you boaſt of for your paſtime Royall?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: She clips the grey and ſhiuer'd wings of Time
to make him ſlow; that our imbraces like
Succeeding minutes then, may adde vnto
Their length. Let me ingender on thy lips—

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: So our progeny may ſtill be kiſſes—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: A meeke and gentle heate, whilſt thus we bill
We imitate the ſober luſt of Doues—

sp.speaker: Scopertae.
sp.l: That kiſſe (Sir) was ſo powerfull and moiſt,
That you haue robd my Lips of all their wealth!

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Take backe thy wealth againe! —

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Are ye ſo hot? —

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy Lips are thin and lanke (Alteza) as
The Lids that cloſe thine Eyes. Hers gently ſwell
Like Eaſterne fruit, and are more ſoft then is
The fleecy Aire that clothes the Infant Morne.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Pray a word! Is there in this Pagentry
Ought like to truth? Diſcouer your intent!

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I'le make my anger equall vnto thine,
And my reuenge aboue them both. This bright
Auſpicious Maid ſhall gouerne in my bed.
She is my Concubine: the Off ſpring of
Her wombe ſhall triumph heere, maugre thy ſight:
Whilſt enuie does conſume thy fleſh vntill
Thy bodie lighter grow then thy looſe mind.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: How well my Starres behaue their influence?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Meruolle, goe! my Miſtreſſe guide vnto
Thoſe lodgings that oreuiew the Garden mount.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: If you retard your preſence whilſt the Sunne
(In's race) fill vp one Howre, you'le find before
Your next reuiew, that griefe hath made me old,
And I ſhall looke more like a Matron then
A Bride; ſo much your abſence mortifies.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thou art to euerie ſenſe I haue, a Spell.
Conduct her ſtrait (Meruolle) to ſome Throne!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Then are the vowes, the Eccleſiaſticke rites
With which the zealous Prieſt oblig'd vs to
Peculiar heate, to abſtinence from change,
And various loue, quite cancell'd by your luſt?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Goe, thou art as light as feathers, or the Aire,
were but an Attome indiuiduall plac'd
With thee in ballance euen, t'would hoiſe thee vp
To th'Cloudes.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Thy breath is fulſome as that ſteame
Which Toades when they ingender vaporate.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Alteza, bath in penitentiall teares
Thy leprous heart, or when the Elements
Are mix'd and the ſad day ariues, that doomes
The world vnto eternitie of ioy,
Or paine, thou ſhalt (like to a glimmering Lampe)
Be hung vpon the ſootie walles of Hell.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I ſmile at thee, and thy thinne Arts; like to
Some homelie Village Leuite, thou doeſt preach
Of terrours ſtrange, to keepe dull faith in awe:
I pray ſtay; I am not angrie Sir.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I practiſd all this while how t'indanger
your ſpleene (Sir) not my owne▪ which if my powers
Prooue iuſt, I ſhall, performe ere long.
Niente, ſend the partie in— Exit Niente.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: A ſlow deuice (Sir) but o'my owne Braine.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: A keene Gueſt, inuited heere—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: Bold ſlaue! be in thy ſpeech more euident.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: I am come to get your children for you.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: D'ye want a cleerer paraphraſe? He is
My ſeruant Sir, my ſtallion if I pleaſe.
A Courtly implement, and much in vſe
Among Ladies of my growth and Title.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: O my cold Blood! My patience will be wrought
So low, that I ſhall learne t'mike a Heifer.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Since I'me ſo aptly furniſh'd with delight,
Your Concubine may feareleſſe walke about
The houſe, and ſhare the wholeſome Sunne in peace.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy tongue I doe neglect: but you (ſir) ſhall
Ere long complaine of your mortality:
The minutes you muſt waſte on Earth are few.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: This I conſider Sir, and therefore make
Such haſte to mingle with your wife; that the
Kinde world may haue ſome iſſue from my Loynes.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: If this prooue true, let Babes piſſe out my Eyes—

div.stage: He drawes his ſword, Sciolto his, Alteza her ſtilleto.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Hold Altamont, or elſe I wound thy heart—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: If you aduance one inch beyond that ruſh
I'le amble through the Streets, and blow your Dirge
With the great Horne that growes vpon your Brow.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: If there be Gall in Heauen, the gen'rall Bagge
Is opned, and it falls in Showres!

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: S'light Sir;
I come t'eaſe the labour of your Body;
And you want courtſhip to returne me thanks.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: But what hereafter I
Performe, ſhall be for your good Ladies ſake,
And not for yours.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Pray (ſir) let's interchange
A little breath: withall (if you conſent)
We'le put our Swords to a more quiet vſe—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Now Sir, you powre ſweet Caſſia in my Broath.
My Blood affects to skirmiſh more
With Ladies then with men. What would you ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: My true opinion ſir concerning you.
I know you doe but countrfeit this luſt,
This lawleſſe heate. You purpoſe not t'abuſe
the Charter of my Bed,

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I read it in your noble feature and
Your lookes. You haue Religion in your ſhape.
And can it be, you ſhould ſo ſoone commit a crime
So much vnwholſome to the Angels ſight?
Let me now make a forfeiture of Eyes,
If euer I beheld a man that's more oblig'd
To Nature for his Limmes: A carnall frame
So full of equall ſtrength I neuer ſaw.
The better ſhap'd I am (Sir) the more cauſe
You'le find, to loue the Iſſue I ſhall get
Vpon your wife.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Doe not belie thy owne
True merits and comport! Th'adulterate fire
Did nere inflame thy ſober heart, I know
Thou ſcornſt to do't.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Not I beleeue it Sir!
Sir I will doe't. Is your Lady fruitfull?
I would be loath t'looſe my labour on her?

div.stage: He drawes, and they as before.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Fling a danger from
Thy arme, I'le ſummon ſtrait (with Trumpet and
with Drumme) the world to heare thy infamie—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O fie! You an Italian Sir, and thus
Behaue the knowledge of diſgrace with lowd
And popular diſlike?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Nay it becomes
You finelie, does it not?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: You thinke becauſe
Y'are curſ'd, we'le allow you ſhort Hornes: I'le graft
Vpon your head a paire ſo tall, they ſhall
Goe neere to pricke the verie Planet (Sir)
Thet rul'd at your natiuitie.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Signior, goe! take downe a Cuſhion, and pray▪
You cannot chooſe but know the frailty of
The times: the ſurfeits of the wombe, and how
Great Ladies doe relieue their Appetites.
Your owne confeſſion of my parts commends
Your wife in her ſage choice. There be that ſinne
With feeble vſhers and the witherd Dwarfe.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: He wants a iudgement to conſider this.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I merit better looks Sir, that muſt thraſh
All night for ye, and without wages Sir!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Dead as a monument! Let vs leaue him!—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Had he the Deuill for's Phyſitian choſe,
He could nere haue come by the like Cordiall.—

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: You ſwelling mountains (that oreuiew the Earth)
Fall now, make me eternally vnſeene!
Philoſophie contract thy meeke ſage brow:
Let Patience be no more thy Saint. As ſoone
Giue med'cines to the dead, teach ſtatues how
To walke, and angry windes to ſleepe i'th North.
As ſoone bid emptie Lions play with Kids;
And to the ſhaggie Scythian ſay, Goe weepe
As Virgines doe, when they their Loues interre:
The blind and ſhuffled Elements that firſt
In Chaos ſtroue, were not ſo oppoſite
As this Religious froſt vnto my heate.
Patience, thou art more fond then teeming wiues,
Tamer then ſſeepe! Diuinitie which calls
Our anger ſinne, and courage pride, hath ſent
This ſillie Cherubine on Earth, Patience,
(The Cowards ſword) which onlie doth diſarme
Dull ſleepe, that neither can nor would doe harme. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Florence knowes me well: I'm call'd Sciolto,

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I needs muſt ſing my vſhers praiſe: he made
A moſt diſcreete election of a man.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Your mercie and your kindneſſe (Lady) thus
Aduance my ſhape; your pleaſure was I ſhould
deſpiſe your husbands frownes, and I behau'd
My ſelfe with terrour maſculine: but now
We are peculiar and reſeru'd, I know
Humilitie, a ſoft and quiet garbe;
A diſtance that ſhall well become the ſtate
So eminent and rich a beauty claimes.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sir, that we doe expect, and then you ſhall
Ore take our noble Senſe, with newer loue.
Our husband is a trifle, ſuch as can
No way diſturbe your peace or ſafetie heere.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Madam, ſtore me with armes and weapons to
Reſiſt his perſonall aſſault, and I
Shall need no more protection then my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Actiue and bold! Niente thou haſt made
A choice out-parallels the world.

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Madam,
See his horſe vaines: th'are large as Conduit pipes;
His Sinnews are like Cables.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Las! not mine!
Tis true, that if I like my Oppoſite,
I haue a tricke te giue an eaſie fall,
And ſtand to't ſtifly too when I ha'done—

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: I will aſſure your Ladiſhip, the Bawdes
Giue him good report.

sp.speaker: Nienie.
sp.p: He's great with Ladies of all ages, all Degrees.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Excuſe me Sir, th'are great by me!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: How Signior? Is your appetite ſo ſtrong?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Blame the humorous Planets that orerule
The blood. Ere yet this preſent Month expires;
(Let's ſee—I,!) Some three and forty Ladies
(Or there about) will quicken with male Twinnes.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: So wiſe Fame ſings.
I will make bold to gather my firſt fruits— Goes to kiſſe her.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Stay my pregnant Signior! Our loue is not
Yet ripe: there is a larger diſtance too
Belongs vnto our Lips.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I am too proud to haue my fauours ſoone
and eaſilie conferr'd. Such ſmiles are cheape.
I meane to procreate by preſcription Sir,
Make my luſt as phyſicall as my meales.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Death, I'm Sutor vnto Gallens widdow!
Madam, I know it not becomes the high
Demeanure of your birth to dance (iuſt like
A Kid) to th'muſicke of each wind that blowes.
Ere you admit of dalliance I ſhould vſe
Some induſtry of Tongue, and flexure of
the pliant Ioints, to court and wooe conſent.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: And can your rudeneſſe couet then where your
Safe wit and knowledge warnes your abſtinence?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Only a little t'recreate the Chine—

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Keepe backe, if you'le continue life. When I
Am pleaſd to be delighted Sir, I can
command the function of your Limmes.
Charintha within. Madam!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Siſter, I come. Throw him to his chamber—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Haſt no good booke, whoſe comfortable vſe
may fill th'expence of time?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Any o'th Moderns. Rablays i'th praiſe of
Midwiues. Aretine on copulation.
Or th'Odes of Theophile vnto his whore.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: My Vſher in my cloſet can appoint
Your choice of theſe.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Thinke on the frailtie of
The fleſh; and be not long vnmercifull—
Charintha within. Siſter! Madam!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Away; I come, I come. Exeunt Niente, Sciolto:

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: The Millaine Count (my Sutor) is ariu'd.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Signior Dandolo! Why 'tis yet a month
Ere he ſhould meet your expectation heere.

sp.speaker: Beſognia.
sp.l: Tis he Madam, and ſuch a he as muſt
Be onely likened to himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: More rich,
And gaudie then the Eaſt. So lib'rall too,
That you would thinke he Natures Steward were.
He giues amongſt m • ſlaues, as if vnto
Embaſſadours he did caſt Donatiues.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Milke him (my Charintha) oft I haue preach'd
Vnto thine Eare a ſou'raigntie ore man.
Take all he giues, it's princely faſhion now.
Could but thy acceptation begger him,
Thy little wit were euer magnifi'd.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: You know I am o'th'wits, I haue bin ſworne
To begger Sutors, and ieere my husband.

div.stage: Enter Florello in rich habit. Roſſa, Molard, ſhifted like his ſeruants.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: Which is the Ladie that I come to wooe?

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: My name's Charintha—

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Preſent me thy Lips!
I ſay aduance —

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: You are not vnderſtood—

div.stage: He kiſſes Charintha, then giues her a Iewell.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: My Lord, I ſcarcely owne deſert enough
T'intice this Iewell from your Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Florel.
sp.l: A Stone, a Stone! the thing growes, I'ue enow—

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: So free? I am Charintha's Siſter Sir—

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: It may be ſo. A fine houſe, fine Towne too!
Were Florence mine, I would not giue it for
The beſt winter Seate my father left me.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Tis Sir, th'ambition of my loue, that you
Would know me for Charintha's Siſter!—

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: I muſt know her for Charintha's Siſter.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Is there no tricke in ceremonie Sir,
To giue your memorie a better hint?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Kiſſe none but thee! A deuice i'th'blood! but
Princes haue one toy or other ſtill, t'make
Their deſcent knowne. — There, a Diamond that,
And that a Ruby.— Giues to Alteza.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Th'are none of mine. I haue enow, weare'em—

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip binds my great acknowledgement.
I'th leaſure of a winke, he'le giue away
An Empire.

sp.speaker: Beſognia.
sp.l: I'm Charintha's woman Sir—

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Who can helpe it? Miſtreſſe, wilt thou not bid
My ſeruants welcome? Th'are rich Choughs, th'aue ſtore
Of Villages, and plough'd Earth.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Their iudgement is
So kind (Sir) as to know they may command
The houſe.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This is my Paraſite, and this my Pimpe.
I'ue a Foole, a Dwarfe too at home. I made
My iaunt too early by a month, or elſe
My Traine had beene enlarg'd.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Th'are rarely fix'd,
If they import as much as you denominate.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I keepe my paraſite to cure the dull
Melancholy of State. He does admire
My wit and Beard. He ſayes I cannot ſinne.
Princes would ſtill be ſad out for ſuch worrmes.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: But how (Sir) does your Pimpe adhere to vſe?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: He is as pertinent to Lords as luſt.
My Foole I keepe to laugh at me. My Dwarfe
Is for my wife. I doe intend ſhe ſhall
Affect the Court, and then ſhe'le quickly learne.
To make the Toy vſefull.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: My Lord, be pleaſd
To walke, and vſe th'aduantage of the Aire.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'ue Inſtruments diſtinct, that take a charge
O'th ſeuerall quarters of my Frame, My Dwarfe
Doth dreſſe me vp vnto the knees, and when
His ſtature leaues his reach, young Virgines then
(Th'iſſue of decay'd Barons) do beginne
And gouerne to the Nauell. Whilſt vpwards
Barbars, Painters, and Paraſites are vſ'd.

sp.speaker: Charin.
sp.l: But will your Lordſhip walke and ſee the ſpring?
We haue a Garden where it euer dwels.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: And ſhall we be delighted and entranc'd?

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: We'le ſacrifice the vtmoſt of our wealth
And loue, t'expreſſe your welcome Sir.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Wilt'I faith.
There's a Saphyre Chaine: Tie thy Monkie in't—
Take it; for by this hand I am in haſte
And cannot offer twice.

sp.speaker: Beſognia.
sp.l: If you ſhould chance
(My honourd Lord) to drop thoſe trifles heere,
I would be mannerly, and reach'em vp.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I will giue thee a Buſhell of Seed-Pearle
To imbroider thy Petticoate.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: This way—

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip hath forgot to leaue notice for
Thoſe Princes in diguiſe that ſhall by chance
Demand ye at the gate.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: A leaſh of Germane Dukes that walke in Rugge.
I ſhould conſult with'em'bout ſubuerſion
Of a State or two; but I'm not yet at
Leaſure.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: My Lord, they ſhall be anſwerd ſo.

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.p: Your hypocriſie wants a little Art.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.p: Your bounty will impoueriſh vs too ſoone.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Ye both doe lie, I weaue my cunning cloſe.
Fortune, redeeme the credit of thy Eyes.
Thou wilt (if thou art partiall now and kind)
But winke on me, though to the world th'art blind.

div.head: Scene the firſt.
div.stage: Enter Altamont, Meruolle. Sciolto at the other doore.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: THis is the truth, therefore conſider now
my Fate. Hah! Sciolto!

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Tis Sciolto, the brute Adulterer,
He whom I lately mention'd in my ſpeech.
A ſlaue more ſalt then is the Balticke ware,
More hot then hell, a Satyre or a Goate.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: And ſhall be ſtill ſo (Sir) vnleſſe your wife
Diſmiſſe her pride, and vouchſafe to coole me.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Deuils and death, I'm murderd through the Eare—

div.stage: He drawes, Sciolto puls foorth a caſe of Piſtols,

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Take diſcipline awhile, Know if there be
A boiſterous motion vſd, I haue for each
Of you a round Synamon Plumme, and they
Shall enter your nice ſtomacks the wrong way—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Though thou wert hardy as the Lions race;
And arm'd with all th'Artillery on Earth,
I durſt aſſault thee as I am; but ſo
I cannot ſatisfie Reuenge.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Sciolto, now my memory begins
To know you better: for your riots bold
And lowd demeanure in this City hath
Beene long obſeru'd. I wonder much y'imploy
Your precious minutes in a courſe ſo vile.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: What, as to copulate and increaſe kind?
It has beene a vocation euer ſince
The Sunne ſpi'd man thus crawling on the Earth—

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: But what excuſe canſt thou in honour vrge,
for wearing ſuch aduantagious defence,
Againſt his iuſt and ſingle violence?

sp.speaker: Seiolto.
sp.p: I haue an odde humor, not to be kill'd.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O Alteza, had but my name beene hid
Beneath ſome fold in the voluminous
Darke booke of Fate, I might haue miſſ'd of my
Creation then, ſo I ſhould nere haue ſeene
Thy face.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: My curſes (Sir) haue cauſe t'aſſault
Her more then yours: for ſhe has ſtaru'd me heere
With want of naturall delight. My free
Large growth and tincture of my haire denote,
My conſtitution cannot ſuffer me,
To weare a ſurpleſſe, or proceed Eunuch.
Though I ſhould bath and ſwimme in Iulips Sir,
I'ue ſtill vnrulie heate about my Chine.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: A Salamander that doth feede and cloth
It ſelfe with flame, was thy Progenitor.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Haue I not equall reaſon to complaine?
In three Houres not ſo much as a drie kiſſe.
Th'old amorous Deacon that imbrac'd his Cow
Was not ſo deſtitute.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: A Negro might be vſefull now, although
Sh'ad but one eye, and that fix'd on her heele.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I'le ſtrew vpon thy food the teeth of Snakes,

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Signior, preſume no more vpon a fond
Eaſie nature. I haue beene abſtinent
Too long. Haſte, and with pliant ſteps preſent
Your wife; Ot elſe I'le aſſure ye you ſhall ſeeke
Some other man to Cuckold ye for me.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I'le ſhoot
Thy heart with needles, ſmall as ſplinters of
A haire that thou mayſt die, and yet not know
That thou art kild.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I thanke ye (Signior) but
We Florentines doe ſleepe like Leuorites,
With our Eyes open: how ere, I could vouchſafe
To ſhoot you now, and preuent your kindneſſe.—

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Sciolto, hold. If eyther charge doe miſſe,
He that ſuruiues, ſhall grinde thy marble heart,
Betweene his teeth—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I meant not to giue fire.
There is a tricke of grauity i'th ſtate
Cald Law. Beſides, you dead, the children which
I chance to get vpon your buckſome wife,
I ſhould goe neere to keepe at my owne charge.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: Africa breedes no monſter like to thee.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I'le to my chamber now, and fortifie
There, I remaine (during the pleaſure of
Your wife) your Tenant (Signior) in fee tayle. — Exit.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: It is a cunning, and promiſcuous ſlaue.
This ſtory of Alteza's abſtinence,
He doth but counterfet, to gull my ſight.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Had the Diuell himſelfe crep't into fleſh,
And vndertooke this ſeruice to your wife,
She had poſſeſſd, the weaker Inſtrument.
He hath in 's Veynes, a moſt intemperat blood
His valour's ſo renown'd, that all the ſmooth,
The curl'd, and ſilken Nobles of the Towne,
Doe homage to his Sword; and by ſuch Actes
As theſe, he glorifies his truant youth.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy fayth was iealous, I ſeduc'd thy eare
To ſhare vntruths: but now, thou knowſt too much.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: T'was my ſuſpect of Fame, and diſperſement
Of your deepe wrong, that manacled till now,
Your hands. My temp'rate Lectures ceaſe. Obey
Reuenge, and I will follow it, vntill
My wealth, and life, are forfeyted to Law.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Hah! wilt thou? O my quickened heart (entomb'd
Before within my breaſt) wilt thou? This, this
Then is the direfull night, wherein I'le giue
A ſtrict and cruell iuſtice to Reuenge.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: This then is the night, wherein my bold loue
Shall merit me th'eternall name of friend.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Come ſweare, ſweare now (on this victorious ſword)
Thou wilt obey th'iniunctions of my wrath,
And yet in perſonall act, not mooue, but when
My will appoints a mixture of thy ſtrength.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: My choice Religion, & the honors of my blood,
I heere doe pawne to ratifie the vow —

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Now worke my iniurd ſpirits, till you make
Dull ſorrow riſe in nimble flame. Anger,
Is blood, pow'rd, and perplex'd into a froth,
But Mallice is, the wiſedome of our wrath. Exeunt.

div.stage: Ent. Florello, Charintha, Alteza, Roſsa, Molard.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: Your Lordſhips letters were of a prompt ſtile!

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This orient Roape is yours, and you muſt wear't;
I ſickne els, and grow a villager
In Elizium!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Take it. Afflict me Fame, if ere I knew
His parallell; he woes at Neroe's rate. Enter Beſognia.

sp.speaker: Beſognia.
sp.l: Madam, ther's a new Dand • lo, a new
Count, lighted at the Gate, and craues entrance.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: That's rare i'faith; haue I a ſhadow walkes
Without leaue o'the Sunne?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Did not Meruolle ſay, t'would be a month,
Ere he ariu'd?

sp.speaker: Roſsa.
sp.p: Be bold and meet your chance •

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Stand firme, and ſtiffely on your ſinewes then,
Auouch me ſtill, for the true Dandolo.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Charintha, 'tis ſome ſtratagem; but if
He Iewells bring, and in a hand as large,
And open as yon'eaſy ſnypes, thou haſt
Ill lucke if thou conſtraine him not to loſſe.

sp.speaker: Charintha·
sp.l: I'le ſmile no longer then theſe rich ſparkles
Shine in my Eies. Enter Dandolo.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: The Lady that is nam'd
Charintha heere, muſt be reueald; for Il'd
Exallt her Lippes, and make'em knowne to mine.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.l: S • light, this is the great Cham. Hearke ye, Signior—

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: My Lord, I pray afford him leave to ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: What, is that ſawcy Groome? Does he ſell Egges?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'le ſhew ye my Trade; A poore ſword-man, I—

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sir you deſtroy the quiett of my Howſe:
He ſhall haue ſafety heere, and leaue to ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: I'm call'd Charintha Sir; proceed to ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: I'le firſt doe ſpeciall grace vnto your Lip—
My Penne hath woo'd you oft; but now by ſtealth
Thus ſingle I'm arui'd, a Moone before
The time I did prefix.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: T'was Winter when I ſpecifi'd the date
Of my aproach, and then my blood was cold;
But now the ſpring is come, Things would couple.
Theſe (Lady) are very ſerculare Pearle—

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I ſir, and in ſuch Toyes, ſhe much delights:
Allthough her modeſty be loath, to make
Her fancys knowne. Would you had brought ſome few
To mach'em.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: I reioyce in all the workes of Nature!

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: That I did ill, to leaue my Pearles behind.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Siſter this Hulke, is neither rigg'd, nor fraught,

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: I'le haue no more of him, he is too coſtiue.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Sir a word. Me thinks you looke, like raw Porke.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: Has not this houſe the priuiledge of peace?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Ladyes, this Impoſtor ſteales my Titles,
And my name, I aske leaue, to puniſh him.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Wee'le not protect his crimes, vſe your iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Vnleſſe you are an Eſtridge, Sir, and can
Digeſt ſteele, coole your lungs, and calmely wayt
Th'inquiry I ſhall vrge.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Molard, reueale how long thou haſt bin Pimpe,
To the family of the Dandolos?

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: About ſome thirty yeeres (Sir.) I'ue procur'd
Both time and place, for your good Fathers game,
Ere ſince he was capable of woman.

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.p: He vſd the Trade (Sir) in his infancy.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: I ſcare could walke, when I began't: the firſt
I brought him was my Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Canſt point, at ought
He did ſome two and twenty yeeres agoe?

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: Diſtinctly Sir. I know that Gentleman,
He was got, on a Tripewife of Lucca.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: O th'action of my fathers loynes!

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'm an old • ew at Genealogies.
This fellowes deſcent I know now, and where
He tooke 's creation too. By chance thus haue
I met forty of my Fathers Baſtards.
Th'are poore, and put me oft to charge. Brother,
Welcome.— Roſſa, giue him a Quardecuſ.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: Bid Kings winde ſilke, and Princes meaſure oats.

sp.speaker: Charin.
sp.l: Your trayne of Paraſite, Pimpe, Foole and Dwarfe,
Speake you at firſt, to be the true yong Lord.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Yet th'other has ſome markes, that doe belong
Vnto a Count, o'th laſt edition too:

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: He ſhould be a Venetian,
By'th' wit, and policy of his courage.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p:
Beauties, were you • hands cleane, they ſhould be kil •
〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: Sir, —you ſhall know,
No man ere got me, but my owne Father. Exit.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Beſognia ſpeake in my behalfe; I'le giue
Thee a Pearle then, big as a Pompeon.

sp.speaker: Beſognia.
sp.l: Which, when your Lordſhip does, Ile returne ye
A pointed Diamond, big as a Steeple.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Y'on thrifty counterfet, has much perplex'd
Your ſeruants wit.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: My Lord. Lets in, and ieere.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Slow method fooles obey. To th' ſtars aduance
His head, who thus reſiſts the power of Chance. Ex. omnes.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Like to my Genius he doth mooue about
The houſe. Our ſoules are ſurely neere ally'd—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Cals he her, his concubine? By this hand
There's not a Prince in all the Eaſt, has ſuch
Another. This Altamont ſtill gripes'em
In the flanke; he knowes to chuſe his cattell.
Be thou pleas'd, O yong and wholeſome Lady!

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: The Garden (Signior) doth containe more walks,
As penſatiue in ſhade as this. I doe
Beſeech you, change your path, and leaue me heere.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: The fumes of ſpicery? you muſt not now —

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: My vowes haue promis'd you the ample truth
Of my intelligence. Behold, whom there,
Sciolto keepes in amorous whiſper.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Hah, Scoperta! Libid'nous Girle, what makes
She with that Horſe?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: No, let'em Knit and generate; my words
Shall neuer penetrate her Eare vntill
I am reueng'd for what my Eyes haue ſeene.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.p: There is a generall tainture in the Sex.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: She is proſcrib'd, I'ue fil'd her in the Liſt
With thoſe that taſte to Night a bitter fate.
Away, away. This obiect ruines all
My faculties. Exeunt from aboue.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I ſigh my firſt ſalute
Was ſo intempratly perform'd. But O!
The iuſtice of my Starres! My loue is now
Reueng'd vpon my luſt. With pure chaſte flame
I Court the Miſtreſſe vnto Altamont;
One heere reſeru'd for ſinfull vſe. Stay, ſtay!—

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: If I am ſeene, my life is forfeited—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Haſt thou not heard my vowes, whoſe violence
And number well might ſatisfie ſuſpect
in wayward Kings.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: How dare I traficke thus
For loue with thee: when thy accompts with Heauen
Are yet not cleer'd that luſt betrai'd thee to?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: With what aduice of modeſty canſt thou
Accuſe my blood; when in this Manſion th'art
Contain'd for the like ſinne?

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Were I well knowne
Vnto the qualitie of thy new loue,
I would reueale my ſelfe, and take from thy
Beliefe the falſe opinion of my guilt.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: If ere I practiſe impious heate agen,
Some long armd Fiend that in the Center dwels
Reach at my foot, and pull me into flames.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Beare witneſſe Immortalitie and Truth
That I'm officiall heere but by pretence,
My Vaines are cold and chaſte as Northerne ſnow.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Thy name, and then my doubts I will forſake?

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Scoperta is my name. I Siſter am
To Altamont; not Miſtreſſe of his luſt.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O dire affinity! my loue is now
Alli'd vnto my hate. Yet Altamont
Nere merited my wrath. It is the wit
The policie of ſinne, to hate thoſe men
We haue abuſd. When firſt I ſpi'd the grace
And luſture of thy ſhape; me thought I lou'd,
And my ſicke heart enform'd me loue was good:

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: And you when I beheld, I ſaid to Heauen,
O make but his immortall part like to
The Garment Nature clothes it in, and h • lle
Remaine a Type, from whom ſhall be deriu'd
The Prophets, and the Kings that rule the Earth.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Her beauties ſo increaſe; that they do make
My comprehenſion poore.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I ſhould haue vſ'd
More leaſure and nice Art, when I did giue
My loue away.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O ſtay, vntill my vowes
Affoord a larger warrant of my faith—

sp.speaker: Scoperta:
sp.l: Our new ſociety muſt not be ſeene.
But if thy loue be free from carnall Arts,
(Such as the curled Youth of Italy
Doe vſe) make me thy ſudden ſtealth▪ Early,
(Ere the ſucceeding Sunne ariue i'th'Eaſt)
Appeare beneath my Caſements view, and I
Will follow thee along the ſpacious World.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Goe noble Maid, wert thou diuided from
My reach, by Sheets of Elementall fire,
By ſtreames of recking blood, by purple miſts
(Which Cannons in their acclamation breath)
Or winds (when met to blow each other from
The Earth) yet I would pull thee to my Heart.
Falſe luſt, I take of thee eternall leaue—

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Conuey thoſe odors thither, and diſperſe
The coſtly ſmoke, about the roome.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Place ſoft and eaſie finger'd Lutes, behind
The Arras; voyces feminine and yong.
And ſpread the Cowch, with the greene Perſian Quilt.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I feele a ſlothfull grudging in my veynes,
And therefore meane to ſolace with a male.
Bruſh thy Beard, and follow me. —

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Now am I
As raſcally a ſinner, as euer.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Is not thy blood well? Kiſſe me Sciolto.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Shall we be wrap't in curlings intricate?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: We'le haue our artificiall heates, and with our own
Panting coole vs to new, and yonger ſtrength.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: And ſhall we 'tweene two ſhady Poplars hang
I'th Indian-Net, whoſe ſlippery cloſures may
Entangle vs ſo faſt, we n'ere ſhall be
Vntied agen▪

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: We'le grow as in one skin.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Yes, much! Not an inch.—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: And ſhall my action more. It mightineſſe
And ſtate, taught me to faſt from fleſh; and now,
I am well pleas'd to make't perpetuall Lent.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: I like this well. My Male is witty growne.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Goe, kneele to your husband, and beg from him
Lawfull recreation: My ſelfe intend
To purchaſe a few Beades, and turne Vot'ry.
She'le nere moue hence, 'till I'ue inrag'd her ſpleene.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: What motiue (Sir) perſwades ye, vſe me thus?

sp.speaker: Scio.
sp.l: Queſtion your Glaſſe! Your Face was caru'd—out of
A Blew Cabidge; and 'tis contracted now
To one, oblique Wrinkle.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Thy aged skull in ſtead of haire
Oregrowne with Moſſe, and lookes as if t'had binne,
A Thouſand yeares entoomb'd.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Thy ſollitary Teeth, in diſtance ſtand
Like the decayed Arches of a Bridge.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Wilt not yet goe?
Thy Fingers are all crook'd, like the Tallans
Of a Griffon. Thou walkſt on Cloven-feete.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Thy Bones are pil'd acroſſe▪
Much like the Stickes on a Coniurers fire.

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: Are my Groomes dead? what hoa! I'le impound ye.—

div.stage: Sciolto pulls out a Caſe of Piſtolls.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: It muſt not be. For with theſe two (of which
I meane to rob your armorie) there ſhall
Be paſſage forc'd broad enough for a Teeme
Of Southerne Elephants. Farwell Oiſter! — Exit.

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: Where are my Groomes, my ſlaues? iniurious wolfe.
Barke at my precious feature, and thus ſtrew
My beautie ore, with infamie and duſt?
Strike my greene youth, with Epethites of age?
My Altamont nere vs'd me thus. He oft
Compar'd me to the Starres, m'Eies t' Eaſterne light,
When day ſmiles at her birth. O! I could curſe
The giddie iudgement of my blood; that thus
Seduc'd me to forſake that Saint, and mix
My knowledge with this Deuill. He's fled too,
Vntouch'd by my reuenge. Niente, hoa! Enter Altamont.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: 'Tis Alteza, I know her ſinfull voice,— (She kneeles.)

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: O Sir, if anguiſh, or diſtreſſe, can make,
An humble heart, behold your Lady now;
That ſhortens thus, her ſtature, at your feete.—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: What may this forc'd humillitie portend?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sciolto (cruell as the windes in March)
Hath ſtrooke, my womanhood, with tyranie,
And ſcorne. Can Fate preſent ſo large a teſt,
Of your true loue, (both to your ſelfe, and me)
As that you miniſter reuenge vpon
His Life. Goe, and ſalute his recreant Heart
With your bright Steele, and then obedience claime
Repleate with fonde Idolatrie, and loue.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The Fiends are ſurelie maried too; for there's
Noe torment like a Wife! falſe Alteza.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: So ill I merit charitie: that all
My paſſions argue cunning and pretence.
This is a wiſe hypocriſie, to hide
Thy luſt, or ſnare me in ſome guilt, whereby
The Duke may claime my life, and thou receiue
More quiet ſpace, t'inioy Sciolto's limmes.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Thoſe angrie ſpirits that reſide below,
In flaming Ouens, are not more cruell in
Their enuie, then am I in hate to him.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: So ſoone, doſt ſteepe him in thy gall, whom thou
Haſt waſht'i'th warme diſtilments of thy heart.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: If ere I knew him, with more guilt, then what
My wiſhes and my thoughts containd; let wrath
Then make me her experiment, to trie
How much of paine, mortalitie can heare.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy periur'd atteſtations ceaſe; for though
The howres are few, ſince firſt you did conferre,
Yet you had both the pregnant thrift, to make
The time aduantagious to ſinne.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Expreſſe,
Some mercie in your faith, and heare me ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Keepe thy deniall 'tweene thy bliſterd lippes.
I • vtterd' thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Doſt weepe? I ſooner thought t'haue ſeene the Flin •
Supple as Spunge; th'obdurate Diamond melt
At the Glow-wormes pale eie.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: How hath the pride
Of Courts miſſe-led my youth, that you ſhould thinke
I'ue loſt, all tender complements of grace?

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Thou wert a Virgin ſweet, ſo precious in
Thy frame, that with the cordage of thy haire
Thou mightſt haue fetterd Kings. Thy voice has marr'd
The beauties of the night. When thou didſt ſing
The quiet ſtars, would fall aſleepe and winke.
Thou art all diſcord now: thy glorie's darke;
Thy thinne, and Roſiall blood, i • turn'd to Inke.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I haue outliu'd the helpe of penitence,
And benefit of hope.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Oft haue I ſai'd
Let's leaue the falſe, the buiſie world and ſleepe
Beneath our vines; Nature (not cunning) then,
Augments our wealth; the dew of heauen is cheape,
Nor need we pay for'th Sunnes warme light, If kinde
Diuinitie allow t'each humane ſoule
A ſtarre; our iſſue w'ele increaſe, vntill
The bright and numerous throng be all imploi'd.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: But I am ſterill as a wilderneſſe,
My name, is ſickeneſſe to your memorie.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Witneſſe you ſilent powers, the crime is not
Deriu'd from me. T'explaine my innocence,
Know, ſhe that heere I houſd, t'affront thy pride,
Was my chaſte ſiſter, not my Concubine.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Then you are loiall ſtill, t'oth Mariage vow.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: But; ſhe treds the ſlimie path. Scoperta,
Is now thy R • uall in Sciolto's luſt.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: All ſprings from the ambition of my guilt. —

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Although thy penitence be raſh, it doth
Become thee well, and thou haſt qui • e diſſolu'd
The ſtonie corners of my heart. This night
I purpoſd thee a cruell death, but now
Riſe, and continue mortall ſtill—I'le lay
My mercy on thy Lip, and for it take
My laſt farewell—. I'le neuer ſee thee more.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: This is a mercy that confounds the will
And ſtrength of all my gratitude. O ſad
Decree. You haue diuorc'd me from your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Two neighboring Lillies whom rude winds diſperſe
'Mongſt reſtleſſe duſt, may ſooner meet vpon
Their ſtalkes agen, and kiſſe each other in
A ſecond growth, then we our loues renew.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Take heede (Sir) how you prophecy! For my
Humilitie with moiſt contrition ioyn'd,
May hope to waſh my leprous ſtaines away.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O no! my iealouſie is growne ſo ſicke, that my
Suſpect enformes me, it will nere be cur'd.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I creepe thus to my Toombe, indebted for
Your loue, till all the drowſie world ſhall riſe
To generall Accompts; and then my want
Of earlier gratitude will make my Debt
A ſinne— Exit.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O triuiall propertie of life!
Some doe attend the mighty warre, and make
Diuinitie their yoake; till for the ſport
Of Kings th'augment the number of the dead.
Some walke in ſlipprie paths of Court, and feede
On ſilent ſmiles; the grauitie of mirth.
Some trauaile in the ſearch of humane Arts,
But knowledge is reſeru'd: She ſits ſo high
In Cloudes, we cannot reach her with our Eye:
Or if with patient ſteps we to her climbe,
Death ſayes we cannot reach her with our time.
For witherd age ariues, when numbring on
Our griefs not yeeres; the tedious ſpace of life
We ſtraite accuſe. For life is like the ſpanne
Forc'd from a gowtie hand; which, as it gaines
Extent, and actiue length, the more it paines. Exit.

div.head: Scene the firſt.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: MY iourney was by ſtealth, elſe I had brought
With theſe, Legions of Dukes to ſpeake my birth.

sp.speaker: Beſognia.
sp.l: My Lady'gins t'enquire (Sir) after ſleepe,
For it growes late.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: My corporall method
I will diſorder, ere I'le miſſe her view.
This Britiſh Groate is thine; traficke for Pinnes.

sp.speaker: Beſognia.
sp.l: Make the Deuill your Factor; Ther's a Stocke
To ſet vp with. Flings it agen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Brother, I wiſh you would auoid my haunts.
Tis not for my credit, nor yet for our
Dead fathers, thus to make your perſon knowne,
Being y'are illegitimate begot,
By the motion of the euill Spirit.

sp.p: Were we his heires, w'had cauſe to haſten his Deceaſe.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: D'ye walke like Neptune in a maske,
Attended on by two o'th calme Windes?

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: Th'are Nobles of a ſupreame race. This is
Stocccata call'd, and that Punto. They both
Are come to warrant my creation good
Vpon the Gauntlet of a Giant or a Whale.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Maintaine your birth—Were you my fathers Bawdes?

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Alas, you are young (Sir) you know not vs!
We cannot ſwell and rant like things that would
Be rather heard then felt: but we can thruſt
Our Whineards home, with ioy and quiet too.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: Sweet heart; you are not read i'th'rudiments
Of wrath. You ſhall perceiue ſome that are lowd
And actiue with their Lungs; Courage in them
You may ſuſpect: but when you ſee a coole
And ſilent anger like to ours, then keepe
Your wandring hands at home. Soft Sir, beware!

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.p: Stay, woo't thou kill him (Punto) or ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: I'ue buiſneſſe now of a more ſerious garbe.
Diſpatch him thy ſelfe. Earlie to morrow
I'le doe as much for thee on the two Zwits.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: D'ye make no more o'th'Infants o'the Earth?—

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Fie Sir. Draw your weapon in a Ladies
Chamber? You ſtill diſplaie a courage ill
Brought vp, moſt vainlie nurturd (Sir) beleeue't.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: Forbid it Heauen; but you ſhould haue free ſpace
T'imploy your beſt ſtrength in your defence.
But Sir, 'tis ſober patience makes vs ſafe.
If now on eithers Haunch you did conferre
A kicke; our ſecret wiſedome would direct
Vs how to beare it for the time, and in
Our owne aduantage too.

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Heare Sir th'aduice of an old ſhot. I'ue hit
The marke more then once in my time, and tam'd
Many a mad Boy too. If either of's
Vouchſafe to greete ye with a hand or foot,
Take it, and be thankfull: le • t by returne
Of wrath, worſe doe enſue.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: He's young, Stoccata, carue him gentlie vp! —

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: They take me for a Capon. What Weapons
Fight ye with, Demiculuering or Drake?

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Steele of Toledo is all we manage—

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: What then remaines but Roſſa and Molard,
Aſſault you two, I, my baſtard Brother—

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: Come Sir,—

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: We'le ierke you with our iron Rods—

sp.speaker: Stoc.
sp.l: Keepe your ſword warme, it 'longs to the ſcabbard—

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: O Sir, your vallor ſtill imports ſome want
Of a diſcreet and temperate breeding.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: His bountie nere will giue me cauſe t'aduance
My wit: he growes much troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: Lady! behold two Worthies here; Dragons
In fight. They come to preach my birth.
Th'are knowne to Fame.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: I ſay th'are Potentates; and they doe awe—

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: Signior, you ſtill forget
The quiet and the courteous wayes of ſpleene.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I will trie your polliticke patience Sir — kicks em.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: You ſee we ſtill are calme —

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: He has but thinne
Philoſophie that cannot ſuffer this —

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: You marmalet Count deſerues as much too.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: I doe oppugne the motion with my ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: Pardon me Sir!
I ſay't alowd; The prowdeſt wight on Earth
Shall not kicke me, excepting your deare ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: I haue priuacies (Madam) for your Eare! —

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: You, and your fierce Champions ſtrait remoue;
Craule hence, and be not viſible agen:

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.p: Enhaunce our pay, we'le kill him in the da • ke.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: Agreed, Six Duck • ts you ſhall number more.

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: The neighbours ſay, fortie Seriants waite his
Departure hence, who giue him a new name.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: Hah! What doe they call him?

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Florello, and
Report him brother vnto Altamont.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: My Eies are infom'd, Two Faces more alli'd
In all deuotes of view I haue not ſeene.
The younger brother vnto Altamont;
Fantaſticke too as Winds, and ſillier then
A ſilenc'd Prieſt. Fate had much preferd me.

sp.speaker: Beſogniae.
sp.l: Madam, it muſt be he. I'ue tane a ſtrict
Suruay of's Noſe; 'tis ſo like Altamonts.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: He is alreadie ſo exhauſt, that his
Wiſe bountie can no more be Argument
For wit: And now to haue this plea for his
Diſmiſſion is aboue my ioy. Signior!—

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Sweet Loue, I haue beene bold to giue away
One or two of thy Farmes to theſe my Foll'wers,
They are kinde wretches both, and loue thee well.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Yes ſaith, They bid me rather then
Thou ſhouldſt thus pine for loue to marrie thee.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Wouldſt view my Limmes?—

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: When you doe make your Chriſtianitie
More knowne, you muſt be call'd Florello ▪

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Fortie blew Fiends wait to arreſt you in
Your paſſage home.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Could your abuſiue Arts make choice of none
But me? Be ſure this viſit is your laſt.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I muſt not, dare not, leaue ye, till I'ue cleerd
The errours in this callumnie—

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Returne,
Or you affront my power, and I ſhall thinke
Your loue, is, as your perſon, counterfeit.
The ſtrength of all my Charitie affoords
You but this Key, which in my Orchard Gate
You may imploy, and free you from th'Arreſt.
Beſognia, I'le to bed. —

div.stage: Florello, Roſſa, Molard looke ghoſtly awhile at one another.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: A ſober truth.
Summes I ow'd when I imbark'd for Piſa. —

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: Now ſhall I, like a melancholie worme,
Feede on raw Rootes.—

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: Sing Canticles of woe!
I muſt e'en goe tagge points in a Garret. —

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This Key, with reſcue o'th'young Rapiers of
The Law will bring vs home.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Faith we muſt all diſrobe, our Veſtments old
Stitch on agen, and morgage theſe to raiſe
A Summe that may aſſiſt my librrtie.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: Creepe in our Rags of Tinder, in our thinne
And duſtie webs agen.

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: I feele a heard
Of ſmall cattell graze on my left ſhoulder. —

sp.speaker: Florellll.
sp.l: O my forward bountie! There's but ſicke hope
My Iewels will returne; ſince cuſtome ſhewes;
What Ladies thus from ther dull Sutors get
They doe preſerue as Tribute to their wit.

div.stage: Scoperta, and her Woman vnder a Canopy.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: The longer moitie of the Night's vnſpent.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Since time grew old, he ſlowly findes his ſteps
I'th darke: by day he ſwifter moues. Get thee
To bed; The Caſements of thine Eies are ſhut;
Impriſ • ning their deare Light.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Come my Sciolto, and confirme the vertue of
Thy faith; or I diſperſe my Soule in Sighs,
And make this Chaire my eaſie monument. Roads.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: All are departed that to Charintha
Made viſit: Your Seruants haue begunne
Their ſleepe, and Guards are plac'd vpon the Gates.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Are my bold Inſtruments in ambuſh laid,
And ſcatter'd for the beſt aduantage of
Their conceal'd action, and their view?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: Expect me then beneath the Garden Mount.

div.stage: Altamont ſteales to Scoperta, and ſhews her his Armes beſmeard with blood.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.p: You ſwelling Cloudes choake my afflicted ſight▪

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The Starres like ſcatterd embers fall. The Teares
Of men doe meete in Seas, and Seas orewhelme
The Earth. Th'amazed Heards howle to the Sunne
For helpe; whoſe Beames ſucke moiſture vp, till he
Hath made the flood his draught; but vomits all
In Showres agen; ſuch as Deucalion ſaw!

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.p: Nature (it ſeemes) is frighted from her health.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Behold my Corall hands, they ſeeme to bluſh
With guilt of humane ſacrifice. Me thinkes
I looke like to a Memphian Prieſt, that had
Diſſection made of Hecatombs t'appeaſe
Their falſe Diuinitie. Alteza's dead.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I want pretence to ſooth my faith: Els I
Would hope your hands depriued her not of breath?

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Fathers that feed on Sonnes, and Sonnes that drinke
Their mothers blood, reach not that cruelty
Which her ſterne guilt did throw into my Breaſt.

sp.speaker: Scop.
sp.l: May ſome kinde Saint, weepe o're your Soule vntill
With holy dew, he waſh this ſinne away.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thou doeſt mis-ſpend thy veſtall charitie.
I'th ſollitary age of Night I come,
To finde thoſe Angells that haue buſineſſe now
On Earth, in Synod heere with thee: hoping
I ſhall receiue reward for my iuſt Act.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: The howers that gaue her opportunitie
To erre, were knowne ſo few; that my beliefe
Concludes her guiltleſſe of the actuall ſinne.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Before the hindmoſt part of her vex'd Soule
Forſooke her thrilling Lipps, ſhe did confeſſe,
Sciolto had perform'd all circumſtance
That doth ingender Man. Sciolto too,
Confirm'd her atteſtation as a truth.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Be deafe (ſweete heauen) to this. Did Sciolto
Iterate her foule ſpeech?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: He did, which I,
Ore hear'd, and forc'd a paſſage to his Heart.
From its warme Throane, I ſnatch'd the aking Lumpe,
And threw it ſtraight vnto a hungry Fiend.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Is he dead too? The Genius of the world
Is ſicke, all Formes muſt ceaſe.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: O Sir, ſhould I reſtraine the flux, my Eies
Would drop from their looſe Stringes inſtead of Teares.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: This obſequie, doth make Compaſſion ſinne.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: O Sciolto. Art thou ſo early fled,
To taſt eternitie, and vnknowne fate.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Stint thy hoarce Dirge, pernicious Whore. I had
Some hope, the interuiew that you inioy'd
Might be enforc'd by his vnruly ſtrength:
But now, I finde it was with thy conſent
Procur'd. Y'haue ſtruggled in each others luſt.
All now is euident as light.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I bring
My innocence, to'th'cleere ſuruay of Heauen.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Though dull, to Men of harſh, ſtrict diſcipline,
Yet know, I haue ſome cunning in my rage.
I came to fright this ſecret from thy Heart:
M • Hands I did not bath in humane blood,
Alteza, and Sciolto are aliue.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: This ioy will make my Heart dance in my Breaſt.—

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Sinke into th'Earth, where ſorrow dwells. Ere yon—
Dimme Morne ſhall adde one Howre vnto her Age,
Scioltos Sowle ſhall take a doubtfull flight:
It only ſtai'd to mingle company
With thine. My anger was ſo iuſt, I Would
Not proſecute thy life; vntill my doubts
Were cleer'd. Goe, goe, and number o're thy Beades.

sp.speaker: Scoperta
sp.l: Is there in all your vaines, no drop (vnmix'd
With Gaule) that from our Mother is deriu'd,
And ſo may tempt compaſſion from your Breaſt?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Alteza mournes, as if t'expiate
A Nation with her griefe. Hadſt thou reueald
Such penitence, it might haue ſoftned my
Decree. But thou art ſowre and ſterne of Soule.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.p: No mercie, for our Noble Mothers ſake?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: M • Mother when ſhe lay, a cold paterne for
The figure on her Toombe, ſpent her laſt breath
In praiſe of thee. Quoth ſhe; For my ſake vſe
Thy Siſter well: th'acqaintance that ſhe hath
In Heauen is great. I'th bloſſome of her growth
She ſhall ore'come the Eies of men, and in
Her Age, ſhe ſhall haue skill in Prophecie.
But O falſe lore! Our Mother kind, (whom I
A Sybill held) thou now haſt proou'd a Witch.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I am too weake to force from your beliefe
Miſtakes ſo ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Goe pray, the Howres are ſwift:
I'ue purpoſd thee a priſ'ner heere till my
Returne. — This is a ſicklie Rhume▪ and not
Compunction in my Eyes. —

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: The laſt of all
My merits ſhall be calld obedience to
Your will: If you doe owe a kindneſſe to
Your ſelfe; thinke on Religion and the Lawes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Nature doe thou direct my ſpleene. The Lawes
Are ſinfullie contriu'd. Iuſtice ſhould weigh
The preſent crime, not future inforence
On Deedes. But now they cheapen blood: 'tis ſpilt
To puniſh the example, not the guilt.
Religion too, on our Italian Earth,
Growes like the Cedar big and high; but yeelds
No fruit. The abiect race of men ſhe doth
Confound with hope, and bids them not obay,
T'augment humilitie, but her owne ſway. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Meruolle, Sciolto, and three Mutes.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.p: Your ſtrength does but intangle ye the more.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I'le not be truſ'd (Sir) like a Pullet thus—

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Leaue nothing that can miniſter defence.
Diſarme him of his Pinnes.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Pare my nailes too.—

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: You ſhall be angerd ſtrait, till you beſtow
The time to bite'm off. Soone as we ſpi'd
You ſcaling ore the Orchard wall; we gueſſ'd
The hopes of your viſit. There haue beene ſnares
Lai'd for your feete, ere ſince you left the Houſe. —

div.stage: Exeunt Meruolle, Mutes, hauing rifled him of his Piſtols and his ſword.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: There is ſome danger in this chance, my dull
Heart beates with ſlow, and ominous leaſure. —
