sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Pale Planet ſhine! It muſt be he. My Eares
Perſwade me they oretooke his voice. Sir, Sir! —

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Hah! Scoperta? A cruell deſtinie
Ha •• murdred all our ioy. endeuouring an
Diſa • md; euen heere 'ith preſence of my Starres.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: There's not a Starre in all the Firmament
Belongs to vs.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O none! Or if there be,
Thei • influence is ſo weake that at
This diſtance Babes may blow'em out. Sure ou •
Creation we haue tooke vnknowne to Fate.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Our loue was of too nimble growth vnleſſe
Philoſophie giue hope, that after death
We may conuerſe; this is the laſt of all
Our interuiewes.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: That fatall Prophecie
Will ſhake my Soule from out my fleſh; and like
Some tame Hermit I ſhall vnwounded die.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: The word that's heard abreuiates our diſcourſe
And li • e: the Sand that limits both is falne
Into the reach of number now: and I
Haue ſpent with thee the haſty time prefix'd
For a deuout imployment of my Beades.
The murderers are within.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Grimme wild horrour!
Haſt thou no weapons there that I may vſe
T'anihilate their vigor and their ſhape?

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Vnto thy Lips I'ld throw a kiſſe; but with
The ſtrings of my poore ſolitary Lute
They' • e bound my hands! —

sp.speaker: Sciolto
sp.l: O my hot rage! I could
Spit fire till I enkindle yonder Groue,
Raiſing a flame that might perplex the Earth,
And make'em thinke Heauen had dropp'd a Planet.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: And I could weepe vntill I quench'd that •• ame,
And drew ſuſpition that a ſecond Flood
Was come to drowne mortallitie agen!

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: This ſudden eleuation of the Soule▪
Preſageth death: as if it practis'd how
To riſe, and climbe ere ſhe begins her flight.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I'le be as calme as are Arabian winds.
Scoperta, ſtay; Vnheard we will conuerſe. —

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: They come, they come, deare loue, for euermore farewell▪

div.stage: The Mutes ſnatch her from the Window.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O for the Giant race, to helpe me heaue
Thoſe Mountaines vp; that I might burie this
Proud Structure and my ſelfe! Yon burlie Oake
(Whoſe Roots reach hell) I'le manage till I pownd
And batter all the Marble into Flowre.—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You haue oreheard, what will your knowledge grieue.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Her Soule is ill prepar'd▪

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: I gaue command
They ſhould awhile delay her death, leſt want
Of leaſure might deſtroy her penitence.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Remaine within the ſummons of my call:
And leaue me heere. I charge thee by thy Vow,
And our friendſhips deare vſe, that thou depart.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Some call me Altamont.
I'ue ſeene thee walke armd like a Magazin▪
With ſmall Artillerie entrench'd: but thou
Art fitly now prepar'd for ſufferance.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Not thy tame ſacrifice, but victorie
I'le be. For naked as I am I will
Reſiſt my death; and ſince vnfurniſh'd to
Reuenge, yet I ſhall trouble thy beſt ſtrength.—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Sciolto, though, thou merit trechery▪
And opposition that, by darkeſt ſtealth,
〈◊◊…〉 of thy luxurious ſoule,
Yet I will giue thee faire and equall Game.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Stay. This I will performe▪
And 'tis to know the rigour of thy might,
What wondrous flame and ſpirits doe poſſeſſe
Thy ſpacious Breaſt.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I'ld learne the prouidence and iuſtice of
My Fate; trie if they'll let me fall before
Th'incounter of thy beaſtiall ſtrength; thou that
Augments't thy ſinnes t'orecome the memorie
Of Heauen: in ſillie hope, th'accompts may be
Vnwillinglie ſurua • 'd, becauſe th'are long.
Receiue thy Sword. —

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: If whilſt we ſtruggle in the pride of hope
Thou canſt ſo weaken my defence, that I
Become diſarm'd; thy libertie is gain'd.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: With ſolemne penitence I could accuſe
My crimes 'gainſt thee: but griefe's akinne to feare.
This great demeanu • e of thy ſpleene diuides
Th'intent of Gratitude. I know not which
T'affoord thee moſt, my enuie, or my loue.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: The moone hath now put on her brighteſt Robe;
My anger too, doth carrie fire enough
To light vs to the charge▪ Guard well thy Heart. —

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: A little reſpite giue,— Muſt we needs • ight?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: You then would couſen me of my reuenge? —

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Yet ſtay! — Know I doe loue thy Siſter well.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Marke (ſweet Heauen) with what exalted triumph
He boaſts the fowle remembrance of his ſinne.—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Stiffe as a columne! —

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Th'Arcadian wraſtler told
Young Theſeus ſo; but he did yeeld as if
His ſinnewes had binne made of ſilke. So fierce?—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I'le worke thy ſtrength ſo low, that Virgins ſhall
Haue power to ſhakle thee with ſpinners Thrids—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thus I will bore thy fleſh, till thou become
Tranſparant as a Sieve—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: This cloſure hath
Intangled vs, let's make another charge?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Euen thus diuided Billowes part, that they
May meete in greater foame—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Wilt thou not bleede?
Not yet?—I skirmiſh with vnbodied Aire.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy guillt betrai's thy hand vnto miſtakes,
And thus my iniurd Spirits greete thy life—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: That Wound gapes like to a yawning Giant.

sp.speaker: Altamont
sp.l: So hot is thy laſciuious blood, that as
I ſprinkle it, it ſcaldes my hands—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I reele
Before thy breaſt, and ſtumble at a Wart—

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.p: Thy Sword's my Captiue now. Meruolle, hoa!

sp.l: • haue ſome courage yet, le • t in my Teeth,
If thou art kinde, come neerer with my Throate—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O the Celeſtiall powers are iuſt. See there,
He bleeds like to a Spring, that borders on
The Rubicke Sea, whilſt I remaine vntuch'd.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.p: Has he not loſt the benefit of breath?

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Stop all his wounds, and giue him time to ſpend
The reſt of's moiſture in repentant Teares—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: My wounds cloſ'd vp, what meanes this courteſy?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: That thou might'ſt leaſure haue to pray. Be ſure
(Meruolle.) when's deuotions haue ariu'd
Vnto a powerfull length; you ſtrangle him.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Can thy young honour ſtoope to ſuch low flight?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Vnto reſiſtance equall, I expoſd
My ſtrength, to try thy courage and my fate.
This was my iuſti • e to my ſelfe: • uſtice
I'le giue to thee: Thy crimes doe merit death.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O ſooth my laſt ambition then▪ be thou
My Executioner.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thou art diſarm'd,
Thy blooming honors now are wither'd on
Thy Creſt. I ſhould depriue my Anger of
Her fame, to be thy actiue oppoſite.

sp.speaker: Sciolto▪
sp.l: Scoperta, ſtay. My Soule ſhall houer ſtraite
With thine. Stay for me in the Milky-path.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Let Italy avowch the iuſt demeane
Of my reuenge. Dull Brittaines know no wrath.
Th'vnskillfull youth, that equall Duell giue
To him that firſt incenſd the blood; but tempt
The curteſie of Fate, ſuch take delight
To ſtroke abuſe, pay Iniuries, with right.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: This way (Sir) leades vnto your Graue. You ſhall
Haue ſpace, to gaine ſome friendſhip with the Saints —

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: A ſudden froſt congeales my Heart; I ſhrinke
Like crooked Age; I am vnwieldy on
My ioynts, as if my vaines were empty growne.—
Wounded. His point has ſtollne into my Breaſt.
Oh helpe. I'ue yet ſome vſe for life. Th'nice ſearch,
I made to know Heaun's ſecret iuſtice is
Aueng'd. (Bold Earth!) I weepe into the Sea,
And ſigh t'augment the windes. Repentance is
An immateriall Salue, it cures th'vnſound
Diſeaſed Soule, but not the Bodies wound.

div.head: Scene the firſt.
div.stage: Enter Niente, Alteza in her Night Gowne.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: A Guard vpon my Gates, and haue they there
Binne plac'd ere ſince the firſt ariuall of
The Night?

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Meruolle keepes the Keyes, ho • le let
No ſeruant be awake about the houſe.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: The Sunne begins to bath i'th'Mornings Teares▪
Haſt thou Lucio call'd, and bid Pytho mix
With him in a ſad Song?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: No more (Niente) ſhalt thou ſeruice doe
For me: laſt night I told thee I had loſt
My vanitie: that courtly Lady ſerue
Who findes it firſt. But leaſt thy wants augment
Thy Sinnes, my charitie affoords thee this—

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.p: Well I'm reſolu'd to mend, or become worſe.

lg.l: THis Lady, ripe, and calme, and freſh,
Muſt now forſake both Time, and Fleſh,
T'adde Light to ſome ſmall Starre.
Whilſt yet aliue, each Starre decay'd▪
But Death leads Beauty to a ſhade
More cold more darke, then Night.
The ſawcy faith of man doth blind
To Deſtine all his abiect kind
But aske not Bodies (doom'd to die)
Since Knowledge is, but ſorrowes Spy,
It is not ſafe to know.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Howle, howle, vntill you wake the inhabitants
Of Graues! till you diſquiet all the Spheares;
And put harmonious Nature out of tune,

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: What meanes this fatall ſummon, that doth make
Amazement cold, as is Iberian Ice.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Great Altamont (your Lord) who ſtill was prompt
To curbe th'incitements of your wrath; threw wiſe
Aduantage from his reach, and ſtruggled with
The bold Sciolto, in an equall warre.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Downe holy flame. When Hope doth ſicken ſo,
I would not haue the power to prophecy.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: The ſurly Lyon, and the teſty Bore,
Did nere maintaine, reſiſtance with like fierce
And ruinous returne of ſtrength: for from
Their Eyes ſuch Lightning flew, that Villagers
(Whoſe early labours till'd the Earth) did thinke
Raſh Phaeton did ſcourge the fiery Teeme
Agen. Sciolto chipp'd▪ gagged with wounds;
Did bleede away his ſtrength. This his falſe Sword
Your Husband bade me proſtrate at your feet—
And 'tis the laſt memoriall of his loue.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Ambiguous Hiſtory! He conquerour,
Yet this the laſt memoriall of his loue!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Wiſe Heauen did mocke your Altamont: for whilſt
Ore ioy'd with victory, he ſpies in's Breaſt
A large deepe wound, and thence his Soule tooke flight.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: O my poore Lord! how ſoone haſt thou begunne
Thy immortalitie. The haſty Sparke
So vp • ard mounts, and then no more is ſeene.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: I'th'laſt remainder of his dying ſpeech,
He briefly told his Teſtament; which doth
Containe imployments ſad, and ſuch as you
Muſt actuate ſtrait. To pleaſe his Ghoſt, ſhew now
A little loyaltie and loue, Riſe, and
Be conducted by my ſlow ſteps. I will
Enforme your knowledge all that he enioyn'd

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Th'obedience which I • canted to his life,
Vnto his memory I'le ſtrictly pay.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l:
You haue a loſſe that doth out-ſpeake complai ••
▪
If ſweete and pliant diſcipline of Courts,
If feats of mighty Warre, or ſober A • ts
'Tis fit your Altamont we ſtriue to raiſe,
Aboue the charitie or skill of praiſe▪

stage.hi: Enter Florello, Roſſa, Molard, in their old habits, Dandolo, Stoccata, Punto, bound.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: Who did aſſiſt your paſſage to this walke?

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: Meruolle Sir, with whom we vſ'd your name.
Doe you obſerue the Count, and his two leane
Ianizaries?

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: Certaine ſtratagems (Sir) haue binne leuel'd
'Gainſt the Prerogatiue of your li • e ro • all.
Molard. Ere ſince the h • pe of day▪ they wai • ed your
Deſcent from the Cloyſter Bridge: but doubting
Their owne courage, and meeting vs diſguiſ'd,
Thus in our originall weedes; they would
Haue brib'd vs for two Piſtolets t'aſſiſt
The proſecution of your death. Our Grace
And ſtrength bound them to their good behauiour.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: They walke like Caterpillers on a Leafe. —
Yeeld me the cauſe why you contriu'd my death.
Giue me a Knife!—

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.p: Here is one belong'd to Hans van Geulicke.

div.stage: Florello cuts Dandolos bonds, and gives him the Knife.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Take your ſelfe ſolemnly aſide and cut
Your Throat! do't ſtrait, and neatly too, y'had beſt.

sp.speaker: Dandolo
sp.p: The motion I d • ſlike, 'tis dangerous.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Haue you three throats, can you reuiue as oft
As you are kill'd, to take new puniſhment,
That thus you mutinie 'gainſt kind reaſon?

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: Theſe thouſand yeeres 't has b • n obſeru'd, th'eldeſt
Brothers of her houſe (Sir) could nere endure
To cut their Throates.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Tis fit (deare Count) that you
Muſt die; I'm els vniuſt vnto my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: With ſapi • nt Arts, we will proiect to ſaue
Th'reputation of your i • ſtice.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: I will promulgate I am dead, and both,
My Champions heere ſhall ſw •• r't.

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Wele venture one
Commandement to ſaue another ſir.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This cannot ſatiſfy. How ere (Sir Count)
If you will patiently accept your death.
I'le furniſh ye with Guides, for your laſt iaunt.
You Punto, and Stoccata too! No more
Of your phyloſophie. Fix Brow, to Brow,
Knock out, each others Braines, and ſhew your Lord
The way, vnto th'Elizian-Field. Doe it
At firſt encounter too; For I'm in haſte—

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Slight Sir, I nere was in Elizium, I.
Nor ſhould I finde the way thither, though Signior
Argos, lent me Nintie Nine of his Eies.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: Then Punto ſhall be conduct to ye both.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: Good Signior, any curteſie but this
You may command. You ſtill doe moſt preſume
Vpon the calmeſt, and th'eaſie Nature.

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: They all are forfeittures to th'Law. If you'le
Beſtow'em but as priſners vnto us,
They ſhall ſuffer, or giue vs large ranſome.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: How? a ranſome? Th • ſe Two are poorer then
Carthuſian-Monkes: leane as a Romiſh Lent.
Slaues, who pretend ſickneſſe, that they may lie
In Hoſpitalls to ſteale the Sheets. Achornes
They eate, ſuch as Weſtphalia-Hoggs doe ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.p: The Count (Sir) will vntie his Strings for'em.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: Ranſome, I'le giue: for I doe hate to die.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: The ranſome muſt
Be ſmall. Shuffle'em together: and pack
'Em hence. I will not heare a ſillable
Of thankes. Roſſa, ſee'em horſ'd for Millaine.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: O diſmall change! does your victo •• ous Sword
Hang now on aged Belt of Bandeleere?
Is your high Plume moulted to a ſprigge, ſmall,
As if 'twere made o'th wing of a Beetle.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Who can reſiſt the frownes of deſtiny?
My ſuffrance giues my merits their reward.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Your ſpeech was wont to be in a more high
Exalted Key: lowd as a Gulph! Your heart
Was full of ligges, and your feet did wander
Euen like Autumns duſt.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Affect ſo much
Humilitie as may imploy your thoughts
With more compaſſion on my ru'nou • fall.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: I threw on you perpetuall baniſhment.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'm come to manifeſt the ſinne of my
Diſguiſe▪ though it proceeded more from hope
T'inioy your perſon then your wealth. Witneſſe
Each nimble Regiſter of humane Thoughts!

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: 'Has got a ſweet and powerfull way in ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This is my reall • hape, in which I doe
Appeare, a thinne and witherd Souldier borne,
I'th'later age of warre: When glorie's ſicke,
And honour triuiall as the ſpleene of Babes.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: He was not wont to vſe this Dialect.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Grant now (thou beautious wealth of Italy)
An expiation for my crimes; For know,
I would be cleane when I ſhall dedicate
My future vowes to th'abſent Altar of
Thy Heart: leſt I doe looſe the vſe of my
Idolatry; and make repentance ſinne.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Doe all harmonious gifts reſide within
Such courſe and humble weedes?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Deſtroy me not
With ſcorne: I know you Ladies moſt delight
I'th'fraile ſurface of the body, in name,
And guilded pompe, which was the fatall cauſe
I practis'd them on you:

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Y' endeere the worſt
Of faſhion vnto vs, by making it
A cuſtome in your ſelues. If men did not
Prouide ſuch follies for our ſight, we knew
Not where to finde their vſe, for they digeſt
Them firſt, then they become our nouriſhment.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Vaine men. We alter our creation ſo
With female ſhapes, that Heauen ſcarce knowes its ſtam •
And Nature (that diſtinction ſtill commands
T'each Sex) forgets the worke of her owne hands.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: I nere beheld a feature maſculine
Till now: had you but thus appeard vnto
My firſt ſuruay, I might haue lou'd in haſte,
And yet excus'd the raſhneſſe of my eies.
I ginne to feele ſome danger in my ſtay.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Ere you depart, a ſmall memoriall from
Your hands, I craue, to weare vpon my creſt,
That it may tempt kinde fate to looke on me,
When I in glorious battell ſtriue; and
I will abſent my ſelfe for euermore.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: I nothing keepe for ſuch ſad vſe, as to
Depriue me of ſo ſweet a miracle.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Grant my requeſt, or I'le purſue your ſteps

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: If you continue ſtill to beg, I feare
My bounty will prooue raſh: and I ſhall giue
So much of loue, as you can ne're repay. —

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: O my auſpicious ſtarres! Should I not now
Make vſe of your good influence, I were
Vnworthy of your care. — Enter Meruolle.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: The choice you make
Can nere deſerue your chaſte and lawfull fire
She is Florello of a heart and ſtraine
Too inſolent for nuptiall happineſſe:

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Thou haſt bin cald my friend. But if thy ſpleene
Continue a diſlike of her, I'le blow thee from
My memory, and with my chiefeſt ſtrength
I'le puniſh thy miſſetake —

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: A des'late griefe
Will more become thy breaſt then this proud rage.
Thy brother's dead, and his deceaſe caus'd by
Her ſiſters pride.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Into my • ares thou haſt a horror powr'd
That hath already ſtiffened euerie haire
On my amazed skull into a Reed.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Wilt thou neglect to cheriſh the ſwift growth
Of our new loues?

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Like to her ſiſter ſhe
But counterfeits a paſſionate eſteeme,
That thy fond Nature ſhe might tempt beneath
Her rule. If Altamont be deare vnto
Thy thought, leaue her, and ſtraight attend his Hearſe,
That in the Chappell waits thy obſequie. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Th' inſpir'd Needle's not more true vnto
The North, the Sunne to his diurnall race,
Nor Riuers to the Maine; then I to thee.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Sorrow and loue, my ſenſes doe diuide.
If I remayne with thee, then only loue
I ſerue, if with ſad fleps, I tread the way
Vnto my Brothers Herſe, I both obey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charin.
sp.l: Thou doſt requite the skornes which I did throw
On thy firſt loue. My deſtiny muſt needs
Be tragicke now: ſince the contracted ſcope
Of all my ioy, reſts in diſeaſed hope. Exit▪

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Behold the Throne, your Lord commanded me
Prepare: and heere you muſt be pleas'd to ſit. —

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Can this aduancement ought refer to your
Delight, or to my Lords laſt Teſtament?

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Iuſtice hath laid her ſword within your reach:
And you haue power to ſh • ath it ſo; that where
You execute, you may a murder doe,
Or ſacrifice. Bring the delinquents in.

div.stage: Enter Sciolto, Scoperta, at ſeuerall dores, each led in, bound and hoodwinkd, by two Mutes.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Thy ſpirit Altamont aſcended with
The loue of all my chiefeſt orizons.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Theſe two were by your husbands iealouſie▪
And hate, ordaind for death: but ere that we
Could actuate his will; his noble breaſt
Receiu'd a wound, that bad him ſtrait prouide
For 's owne eternity. The laſt of all
His ſpeech, referd them both vnto your power.
You may appoint them liue or die: and I'm
Oblig'd by vow, to ſee perform'd what you
Command.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Your Iewels, and your wealth, I haue pack'd vp,
To eaſe our flight, when we haue finiſh'd
This vſurpation of the Lawes. Let them
Inioy their eyes; that they may know their Iudge.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.p: Keepe them diuided from each others reach▪

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I thought thy beauties had beene darke and cold,
And th'adſt (ere this) begun an eaſie ſleepe
Within thy ſilent Graue.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: And I ſuppoſ'd thee fled
A Harbenger to Heauen: with purpoſe to
Beſpeake my Billet neere to thine.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Since this ſad night, did blind the drowſi • world,
They thus haue manacled my ſtrength. They'ue watch'd
My hardy violence ſo tame, that now
Each featherd Forreſter rooſts in my Beard.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: We cannot (Sir) be mortall long; therefore
Receiue a hope our ſufferance will ceaſe.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Sciolto, now requite the leyſure I
Haue giuen thy penitence, by rendring ſtraight
Vnto the world, how farre thou didſt corrupt
Theſe Ladies with thy guilt. For know, I ſtill
Perſwaded Altamont thy luſt inioi'd
No more, then what concern'd wiſhes or hope.
And I was vſher'd to'th beliefe of this,
By knowledge of thoſe ſecret ſpies which he
Imploy'd to watch your perſonall remooues,
About the Houſe: whoſe labours euer miſs'd
Of finding that ſucceſſe he prophecy'd.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I doe confeſſe m'imagination once
Did ſinne againſt them both: but if it ere
Extended vnto act; let me loſe Heauen▪

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: If Altamont were now aliue, he would
Permit this vtterance cleere his fayth. Madam,
You heare that he Scoperta vindicates
By oath; though his owne crime doth carry an
Import more euident, and blacke; but yet
When you behold his feature, and his youth,
Your mercy may conceiue t'were pity that
He ſhould ſo ſoone depart from time and fleſh.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sir, you haue skill to know my womanhood
Is weake as ignorance, or ſleepe. Why ſhould
You ſeat me heere, thus to diſpoſe of Law:
That ne're knew any iuſtice, but reuenge.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.p: Your ſentence I am bound to execute.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Haue I not heard you ſay, my Husband did
Ordaine them both for death? T'would ill become
The duty of my knowledge t'alter his
Decree.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Keepe your intent, I will vſurpe
The office of your tongue. Mutes, ſtrangle them.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: If in thy functions, gentle Nature claime
An intereſt, let vs imbrace, and vſe
Solemnity, before we doe forſake
Each others view.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: I grant what you
Requeſt: make your performance ſhort; whilſt I
Reueale m'opinions (Lady) to your eare.

div.stage: Sciolto, and Scoperta kneele to each other.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O Scoperta! this is the laſt of all
Our buſie dreames; what we poſſeſſe is but
Imaginary now: Thy ſhadow I,
Embrace, not thee: for like to it, thou'lt flie
From my enioyment, and no more be ſeene!—

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: So much of various fate, ſo ſoone expres'd
Two louers yet nere knew; ſince ſimpathy
Firſt dwelt on Earth.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Ere long we muſt be cold,
Cold, cold my Loue, and wrapp'd in ſtubborne ſheets
Of lead: hows'd in a deepe, a gloomy vault;
Where no ſociety will mix with vs,
But what ſhall quicken from our tainted limmes.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Whilſt ſtill ther's noiſe, and buſines in the world;
Whilſt ſtill the warres grow loud, and battels ioyne;
Whilſt Kings their Queenes ſalute in Iuory beds.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: But O! how many Ages may ſucceed
In Heauens darke Kalender; ere we agen
Materiall be, and meet in our warme fleſh?

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: And whether that our ſoules, when they're prefer'd
To taſte eternity will euer thinke
Vpon the bargaines of our humane loue,
Is vnto me a deſolate ſuſpence.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Phyloſophie doth ſeeme to laugh vpon
Our hopes, and wiſe Diuinity belies
Our knowledge, with our Fayth: iealous Nature,
Hath lock'd, her ſecrets in a Cabinet,
Which Time nere ſaw: and he that in it prys
Vnto Religion forfeites his bold Eies.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Our Reaſon frights our Sences to diſtruſt.
My Lipps doe beage from thine a Legacie—

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O ſad acomp • . How is my bounty now
Exhauſt: This is the laſt I ere ſhall giue—

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Blind them agen and ſtay their deaths awhile.
Madam, your knowledge is allready taught
Scoperta's innocence. Sciolto's deed
Stands nere your puniſhment; but diſtant far
From remedy. Marke, his goodly feature.
With what magnificence he's built? Beſides
This Morne▪ his Vnkle too (the wealthieſt of
Our Senators) is dead, and has bine pleaſd
T'intitle him his Heire.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: Thinke how you lou'd him once. He will (to ſaue
His life) d • ſcard Scoperta's intereſt,
And marry you: a hapineſſe compleate
For both

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Slaues. Stretch now your Cordage out,
Pull till my Eies do • ſtarte like Bulletts from my Skull,
Murdering where they flie—

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Hold. hold. — Did my
dead Lord bid you performe, what I decree?

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.p: He did: and I aſured it with my Vowes.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Heare then without reſiſtan • of my breath,
Sciolto is condemn'd by Law; as knowne
The fatall Inſtrument that did depriue
My Lord, of precious life; ſo he muſt die.
T'were fit my care affected mercie in
Scoperta's dome; ſhe's Siſter to my Lord:
But her ſweete innocence doth make her ſafe.
She muſt remaine among the liuing ſtill;
And in her rome, I doe condemne my ſelfe.
For my ſterne pride, was the originall cauſe
Of this blacke Tragedy. Kind 〈…〉

Eſteeme your Vowes, ſee my edic •
〈◊〉
▪
And giue me pri • iledge firſt to 〈◊〉

its wrath—
She deſ ••• ds.

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.l: This carries wonder in't

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I'le not reſigne theſe bonds of Death, vnleſſe
Sciolto ſhare in the compaſſion too—

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Giue me your pardon (gentle Mayd). I haue
Depriu'd you of a Brother that deſeru'd
More Pyramids, then all th'Egiptian Kings.
Inſtead of him, receaue my pray'rs, my wealth.
When o're his Herſſe you raiſe a Monument,
And fix my Marble-Figure neere to his,
Create me weeping.— I ſhall goe, with ſo
Much ſorow, to my Graue, that being dead,
My Aſhes will haue power to penetrate
The Stones. Releaſe this pious Lady and
Performe your execution vpon me—

stage.hi: One o'th' Mutes pulls of his Ʋizard & diſcouer • himſelfe to be Altamont.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Away you dreadfull Miniſters of death.
The Lawrell Sprigge, the Mirtle nicely wreath'd
In Coronets, my Loue deſerues; for ſhe
Is growne too good for Earth. —

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: My Altamont. — She ſinkes.

div.stage: Meruolle vnmuſſles, and vnbindes Sciolto, and Scoperta, who ſtraight embrace each other.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: This deceipt brings wonder, great as our ioy.
They that diuide vs now, muſt vſe the ſtrength
Of ſwelling floods, and helpe of Thunder too —

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Put all thy beauties on agen, and ſmile
At the returne of our long abſent loue:
My wound is clos'd, and will hau • inſtant cure —

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: The Earth groan'd at my fall, ſo heauie are
My ſinnes, ſo much they did increaſe my weight.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Riſe gently like a flame, from incenſe ſprung.
Meruolle, to appeaſe my iealouſie
Ordain'd me this diſguiſes that I might heare
How in your ſ • ntence you behau'd your loue
To me: Hadſt thou continu'd falſe, I had
Increas'd the anger of thy fate: but now
Thou art indeer'd vnto my heart agen. —

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sir, I haue hope my future loyaltie
Will manifeſt, your mercie well beſtow'd.—

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Scoperta, thou'lt excuſe the cariage of
My doubts, I look'd on thee with th'eies of loue,
And loue is ſtill too ſtrict in her ſuruay. —

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: My memorie wou • d ſinne, ſhould it record
Ought that might nouriſh my diſlike of you:
You made me taſte of ſorrow, not of wrath.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Tis I, that haue moſt • eedfull vſe of your
Kind charitie: forget my errors paſt,
And to oblige my future gratitude
Giue Hymen leaue to know your ſiſter for
My wife. • y Vnkles death hath lent me power
Still to maintaine her in ſuch qualitie
As ſhall become my deere reſpects to you,
The greatneſſe of her virtue, and her blood.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Take her, and be as tender of her health,
As Heauen hath o're thy wounds; which in their cure
Expreſſe much miracle. — My io • 's ſo ſwell
My breaſt, that I doe finde there's danger in
Delight. How bleſs'd Meruolle are thy Arts?

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.p: Some Angels care aſſiſted the ſucceſſe.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Not Altamont's returne to life, nor yet
Sciolto's and Scoperta's glad repriue
Nor all the ioyes in reconcilement of
Your loues expreſs'd, can my cold ſences pleaſe:
Florello is vnkinde. —

sp.speaker: Beſognia.
sp.l: The little God
Hath lately prick'd her with his baudy ſhaft.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Tell me Charintha, is thy loue ſincere:
Such as i'th ſimple youth of Nature is
Exchang'd by louers with a harmeleſſe plight?

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: It is ſincere, as holy Hermits vowes,
And true, as their confeſſion at their death • .

sp.speaker: Meruolle.
sp.p: Appeare Florello, and receiue thy doome.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: It was Meruolle's care thus to aſſure
Thy Miſtreſſe reall loue, and conſtancie
Ere thou ſhouldſt giue too much of thine away.
But now receiue her from Alteza's hand. —

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Charintha, thy election is ſo ſafe
Thou neuer wilt repent the iudgement of
Thy ſight. He cannot be ſo neere alli'd
Vnto the blood of Altamont, but he
Muſt needs participate in virtue too.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: We will embrace each other vntill Age,
Depriue our courteous ſinewes of extent. —

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: The gentle Turtle ſhall direct vs how
T'augment our loues; the Eagle to renew
Our youth, and we will ſtriue to imitate
The crooked Vine in our increaſe. —

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Ioy, ioy!
The firmament is now vnmask'd, and each
Of vs, hath found his ſtarre.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: My Lou'd Siſter,
I haue orchear'd the ſtory of your griefs,
And from this noble Signior, I muſt begge
A faith indeer'd, the name of Brother too.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: You ſhall be precious to my eies as day.

stage.hi: Enter Roſſa, Molard, fantaſtickly cloth'd in Dandolo's habit.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: The great Dandolo and his Giant whelpes
Are mounted on a Mule.

sp.speaker: Roſſa.
sp.l: Naked they ride
As ſcoutes of Tartary they're victual'd with
A ſingle egge.

sp.speaker: Florel.
sp.l: Th'are ſuch your knowledge ſhall affect: they muſt
Inioy what I atchieue. Dull men, o'war,
The Trophie of my victorie behold,
She's mine: bow, and doe homage to her lippe. —

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Still thou doſt mourn (Alteza) like a Doue. Soft muſick▪
Hearke, hearke how the Roman-Organ ſeemes
T'inuoke the Thracian Lire; the Cymbals of
Iudea, call Caſtilian-Cornets foorth,
And German-Viols wake the Tuſcan Lute▪
The ſacred noiſe attend, that whilſt wee heare,
Our ſoules may dance into each others eare.
